Gareth had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death. His mother said he visited a GP with a rash but tests are needed to confirm the cause of death. The family is unsure how Gareth contracted measles, as no close family member has it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

The passage reports that Vincent Hudson, aged 54, from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense on a boy under the age of 16. The alleged attack occurred in 2001. Hudson is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The passage describes a closely contested match between Gateshead and Guiseley in the National League. Guiseley took an early lead in the first half through an own goal, with Jake Lawlor scoring an empty net goal off a pass from James Hurst. Gateshead responded with a goal by Wesley York in the second half, after Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston's initial effort. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with key substitutions made by both teams throughout the game.

The passage discusses Bristol Sport Ltd's plans to replace two stands at the football club's stadium to increase capacity, as an alternative to constructing a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is facing delays due to a town green application. The project received approval from Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club's intention to proceed with the work at a shareholder meeting. The club aims to sign the section 106 agreement soon and will wait for the judicial review period to conclude before moving forward with the redevelopment plans, starting in May if there are no delays by March.

The passage discusses a 1.5 magnitude earthquake that occurred near Poulton-le-Fylde, Lancashire, as a result of shale gas drilling (fracking) by Cuadrilla Resources. The drilling has been temporarily suspended as a precautionary measure, and Cuadrilla will analyze data collected by the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume operations. The BGS has also been monitoring the situation as a precaution, and has stated that any process that injects pressurized water into rocks at depth can cause earthquakes. The passage also mentions that there have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in the county in March. The CEO of Cuadrilla Resources, Mark Miller, emphasized the company's responsibility to share information and consult with relevant authorities before making a decision on the future of the fracking operations.

The passage recounts a trial involving Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, who was found guilty of one count of fraud and cleared of two others. Carpenter played with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, leading to the fraud charge. Sgt Chris Gaynor testified that Carpenter gave the impression of collecting cash for the campaign, but Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and had previously piped for the charity. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign's Kenneth Derbyshire allowed Carpenter to use the banner but specified it was not for collecting funds. Carpenter maintained the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive. He will be sentenced in January.

In a comprehensive 3-0 victory, Ipswich Town secured a win against Queens Park Rangers, lifting them four places to 14th in the Championship standings while Rangers slipped to 15th. Grant Ward opened the scoring with a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney capitalizing on a miscue by QPR's Alex Smithies. Cole Skuse's long-range shot set up Tom Lawrence, who added a calm finish. Ipswich had several other chances, including Christophe Berra and Skuse's efforts. QPR offered little in attack, with Sandro's header against the post being their most notable threat. Ipswich had failed to score in seven of their previous 10 Championship games, but their performance against QPR showcased their potential.

The passage discusses the impressive performance of Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, in the T20 Blast last season, where he scored 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. Wells expresses excitement about the club's progress and the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, a National Two South team, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were key players. The team will face seven lower-ranked opponents and league leaders Old Elthamians in the upcoming games. Coach Churcher sees potential for improvement and emphasizes the importance of building on recent successes.

The passage describes the arrest of 28-year-old Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun in Kolkata. The incident led to widespread outrage and street protests across India. Nazrul, identified through CCTV footage, fled to Bangladesh but was later arrested upon his return to Kolkata via train. The police have made six arrests in total, with two suspects still at large. Milon Sarkar, initially arrested as the gang leader, had a unclear role in the crime. The attack involved stealing money and ransacking the convent school before the nun was raped.

The passage is an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discussing the reasons behind changes in consumer buying habits. Key factors include the introduction of the domestic freezer, cheaper washing powder, and affordable imports. The video also highlights the evolving ownership and ranking of top UK brands.

The passage describes two incidents of telephone scams targeting elderly individuals, both claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by a scammer who gained remote access to her computer and took money. In the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller claiming to be from BT technical support gained remote access to her computer. The ease with which these scams occur and the significant amounts of money taken are alarming. PC Siobhan Pellett advises people to be cautious when answering cold calls from individuals requesting remote access to their computers and to never share banking details or account numbers over the phone, as reputable businesses would not ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has been appointed as the new coach of Featherstone Rovers for a one-year contract. He left Swinton Lions to lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone's chairman, Mark Campbell, praised Duffy's work at Swinton and his assistant, Stuart Littler, has taken over at Swinton.

The passage describes a rescue operation involving the Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter. They were dispatched to Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on a Sunday. The incident involved a female rider who suffered head injuries and was in a cold, unconscious state on wet sand. The medic treated her injuries before she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

The passage discusses the decision made at a UN conference in Geneva to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve on the current tracking system that relies on ground-based radars. The decision was influenced by the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. Representatives from over 160 countries agreed to set aside a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU). The new system will enable satellites to receive ADS-B transmissions from aircraft, allowing for real-time tracking of planes anywhere in the world. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

A concise summary of the passage would be: 

18-year-old Julian Hernandez, who went missing when he was five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and charged with tampering with records. The FBI received a tip on October 30th that Julian might be the long-missing child after he encountered issues applying for college. The agency, along with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. Authorities suspected Julian's father as a possible culprit during the time of his disappearance.

A fire on 2 March on Duncan Street led to several days of firefighter presence at the site, affecting train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire. Although the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, giving the company until 7 August to appeal. The site's operators, Asset and Land Group, have been compliant with fire safety legislation in the last 12 months. The fire service raised concerns about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment, which the EA took action on. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, linking them directly to the situation in Ukraine, particularly the Crimea region where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill aims to amend Russian law to allow for the annexation of a neighboring state's territory without a treaty, if a referendum or a plea from the territory's leaders is presented. The second bill would speed up the process of issuing Russian passports, allowing Ukrainians to apply for them before August 1st and becoming citizens after two months instead of a year. The preamble of the second bill refers to supporting Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing a "brown threat," likely a reference to World War II fascists. Several Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea in support of these proposed bills.

The passage discusses the history and current predicament of McLaren, one of Formula 1's most successful teams. It highlights McLaren's past achievements, including 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The team's recent slump began in 2013, with issues in chassis design and more recently with the Honda power-unit. The passage also touches on the team's past scandals and the return of Fernando Alonso to McLaren. Despite these challenges, team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about the future, believing McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance in Formula 1.

A concise summary of the passage would be: On January 27, 44-year-old Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was found severely injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and are in police custody. The shooting occurred when Baker left the gym and got into his car. Detectives believe the assailants had been waiting for him for an hour. A silver VW polo, possibly connected to the incident, was last seen fleeing the scene. Police are still searching for a silver VW polo and are appealing to the public for help, especially regarding a CCTV footage of people near the meat market who have not come forward yet.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy a more spiritual Christmas online, despite the commercialization of the holiday. It highlights five examples: 

1. Everyday Church Online, a virtual church service accessible to a global congregation through the internet.
2. Guardians of Ancora, a fantasy game for children that incorporates Bible-themed quests during the Christmas season.
3. Viral.de's The Digital Story of Nativity, a highly successful nativity video featuring social media updates.
4. The Churches Advertising Network's Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle, a creative and budget-friendly Christmas ad.
5. Next Manga's Manga Messiah, an e-book version of the nativity story available in 33 languages, including a recent donation of Arabic copies to Syrian and Libyan refugees.

The passage also mentions the use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram by religious groups to connect with their communities during the holiday season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is considering a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit, with backers including Blaenau Gwent council offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have presented conflicting accounts on whether the circuit would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude that the replacement land is of equal value but is not opposing the development overall. The developers' ecology report claims there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity due to habitat enhancements nearby, which the Gwent Wildlife Trust opposes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the Ebbw Vale inquiry, with final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

The passage discusses the reaction to a report by Novaya Gazeta, a Russian newspaper, which revealed that over 100 people in Chechnya had been detained on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. Chechen Muslim clerics met to condemn the report, stating it insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, and called for retribution against the instigators. Novaya Gazeta urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred towards journalists. Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechnya's authoritarian leader, denies the allegations and claims there are no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechens' spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed retribution was part of the resolution. Novaya Gazeta's report mentioned detainees included some influential Muslim clerics close to Kadyrov and two well-known Chechen TV presenters. The Russian LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution in Chechnya and accuses Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses. If Russia fails to prosecute, they plan to file a case at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

Investing Solutions, a company that operates across seven London boroughs, is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making it highly profitable. It finds properties for single homeless men and works with Fresh Start Housing, a charity that finds clients from London homeless charities. The letting agent charges several unrelated people in one house and charges housing benefit for each person, making the total benefit payout higher than the rent fee passed on to the property's landlord. Investing Solutions was set up in 2002 by Samir Patel, who also founded Fresh Start Housing in 2010, which aims to help current and ex-offenders and reduce poverty, sickness, and distress. Investing Solutions focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35, who can be housed in private rather than shared accommodation. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions more than £2.1 million over the past two years. Critics argue that the relationship between Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing is a "new low," but Samir Patel insists that Fresh Start Housing is an independent charity with its own board of trustees.

In a closely contested basketball game, the GB team, led by Coach Joe Prunty, played against the Dutch team. The GB team, featuring Olympian Andrew Lawrence and NBA player Ben Gordon, led for most of the first three quarters but were overhauled by the Dutch in the last 10 minutes. Despite a comeback in the last six minutes, the Dutch won 71-60. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, noting that he had a good showing, especially in the third quarter. The GB team is now beginning their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary.

The passage discusses the negotiation and approval process for the use of lighter gloves in the highly anticipated boxing match between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather. McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) hours before the deadline, which will now be debated on August 16. The NAC rules state that fights at 154 lbs require 10 oz gloves, but lighter gloves can be used if a waiver is signed and the commission feels the move is justified. Mayweather initially posted on Instagram that he would be wearing 8 oz gloves, but had not submitted the necessary waiver document at that time. The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, studied information on McGregor and concluded that there were several reasons to approve the fight, including McGregor's impressive record and his granite-like chin. Bennett advised McGregor's camp to hire a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Hall of Fame official Joe Cortez, who has overseen an "out of control" sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi.

The passage discusses the history and decline of Fleet Street, a significant location in the British journalism industry. It highlights the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, with reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith reflecting on their experiences working in the area. The passage also touches on the origins of Fleet Street as a hub for journalism, the impact of technological advancements and the rise of media tycoons like Rupert Murdoch on the industry, and the transformation of the physical space once known as Fleet Street. The last two journalists working there, Sherriff and Smith, express their feelings about the end of an era and their roles in the history of journalism.

The passage discusses J.K. Rowling's response to abusive comments on Twitter regarding her political donations and views. She expressed feeling her personal line had been crossed by some users and mentioned being called a "traitor" for her political views. Rowling also shared her stance on standing up to bullies and not protecting the image of any political party. She mentioned engaging with both negative and positive comments from Twitter users, including some SNP supporters with whom she agreed politically.

The passage discusses a study conducted by the University of Edinburgh's School of Law, titled "The Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime." The study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action as better-off children for the same crimes. Living in poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 to better understand changes in their behavior and lifestyles. It identified poverty as an exacerbating factor that increases the likelihood of young people committing crimes, even after considering other risk factors. The study also found that people living in extreme poverty are more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime. Gender was identified as a powerful predictor of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds being twice as likely to be involved in violent crime. The study has been published in the Scottish Justice Matters journal.

A 25-year-old man, Mr. Haugh, was stabbed to death in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and is remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested in connection to the killing were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. Det Sgt Padraig Frawley stated that it will be alleged that Walsh and two other individuals entered the Marian estate to find Mr. Haugh, leading to a fight where weapons were used. Mr. Haugh suffered a fatal stab wound and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. A knife handle and a blade, with blood on it, were recovered at the scene. The judge mentioned the tension in the Kilkee area due to the incident and remanded Walsh in custody until August 14.

A Fermanagh MLA, Phil Flanagan, tweeted an offensive comment about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The tweet was about Elliott's past and insinuated harassment and shooting of people while he was a member of the UDR. Elliott's past was brought up in a BBC radio programme. The tweet was deleted by Flanagan within an hour and an apology was issued. Flanagan will have to post an apology on Twitter stating that his tweet about Elliott was untrue and wholly without foundation. The High Court is yet to decide the amount of compensation. Flanagan's insurance firm has refused to cover any compensation and costs in this case, and he is challenging that decision in a separate court action. Tom Elliott has expressed his disappointment that the matter took so long to resolve but is delighted with the result.

The core pieces of information in the passage describe the growth and expansion of Hawick Knitwear, a company that dates back to 1874 and was acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November of the previous year. The company has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand, with production now at 9,500 sweaters per week, up from around 7,500 last year. The increase in production is due to a surge in orders for both private label clients and the company's own brand. The company has a presence in various markets, including Europe and North America. The managing director expresses optimism about the company's future, attributing its success to the dedicated staff.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, suffered serious head injuries outside a school in Kempston when a 55-year-old man, Brian Wright, failed to stop for a red light and hit her. Wright admitted to striking Blackburn but claimed he was blinded by the setting sun. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial continues.

The passage describes a NATO exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose" where a German U-boat, U33, is used as a training tool to simulate a Russian submarine threat. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for the U33 and its crew of 29, who are trying to evade detection and target the command ship, USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. The training is aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities and addressing growing concerns about Russia's increasing military strength and submarine fleet. The exercise also highlights the challenges of locating submarines, the need for advanced technology like underwater drones and long-range maritime patrol aircraft, and the vulnerability of nations like Britain, which no longer has its own maritime patrol aircraft.

The passage describes the escalating violence and displacement in South Sudan, with potentially genocide and ethnic cleansing occurring. Over 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to Uganda, with the UN reporting more refugees than any other country this year. The conflict is primarily ethnic, with Dinka tribes attacking other tribes, including Equatorians and Nuer. Uganda is accommodating the refugees, providing land and resources for them, but is struggling to manage the influx. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator in northern Uganda urges the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence, which is resulting in civilian massacres on both sides.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old professional boxer since 2013, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12th November. He has an eight wins and one draw record from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive £33 million from the coalition's £330 million investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, an X-ray facility, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped, with Matron Sue Taylor describing it as "very old," "poor old tired building," and in need of constant maintenance. The total cost of the new hospital project is £33 million, with the remaining balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to be built on land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, with a target completion date of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city center, in what appears to be a targeted attack. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest, and the area was sealed off by armed police. The victim later died at the hospital. The man was a member of a local family, and the shooting occurred during a family celebration when relatives came out to help him after hearing the shot. This marks the first shooting in the Upperthorpe area in recent weeks, with previous incidents happening in the north of the city.

The passage discusses the activities of three Ukrainian hacker groups: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for DDoS attacks, hijacking CCTV cameras, and targeting rebel websites and payment accounts. They also monitor public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas of eastern Ukraine. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Anonymous International, known for publishing leaked Kremlin documents, focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but has also covered Ukraine. All three groups operate independently and are involved in various cyber-attacks against separatist forces and Russian interests.

The passage recounts the emotional farewell speeches of veteran MSPs Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Tricia Marwick, who are standing down as MSPs ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's unity and the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for the governance of the country. He also discussed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill and expressed concern that the bill did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system, and Goldie joked about missing her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage discusses the initiative by Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, to gather the experiences of pensioners and their families regarding residential care. The aim is to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies to improve the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. Rochira's review will focus on the quality of life, highlighting both good and poor care experiences. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. It will also involve discussions with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The passage also mentions the concern of Care Forum Wales, which feels that the commissioner's advisory panel lacks representation from individuals with experience in running care homes, potentially missing an opportunity for partnership and engagement within the sector.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5 million in the year to June 2016. Despite a £1 million decrease in turnover to just over £100 million, the company experienced growth in international sales, particularly in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges the difficulty in predicting the agricultural outlook but remains confident in its position to face future challenges, including the impact of Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, and an 80-year-old man was taken to the hospital. Police are investigating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the case. Ian is described as a white male, 6 ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and an average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Detectives have warned people not to approach Ian and have urged anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers. Police are conducting additional patrols in the area for residents' safety.

The passage discusses David Lipton's speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington, where he highlights the risks facing the global economy. He mentions the IMF's latest reading showing a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. The comments are prompted by weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, leading to a potential downgrade of the global growth forecast from 3.4% to an unspecified lower number in April. The implications of this dismal economic outlook have ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that rely on China's growth.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to discuss the issues surrounding the new vessel at Cowes. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until July 2nd to address the problems and allow feedback. The council has ordered an auditor's review of the project, which has been a "frustrating and disappointing start." The chain ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues. Local businesses, including shops and car rental services, have suffered losses. The council is considering compensation for these businesses, as well as for damaged cars. The ferry company has fixed electrical problems and the council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage.

A crash involving several vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was fatally injured and pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Matching Models, an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people, for advertising a personal assistant position with specific physical appearance requirements. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has labeled the advertisement "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women." The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends the practice, stating that looks are important to their clients. The EHRC is set to write to Matching Models requesting clarification on their hiring practices. Employment lawyer James Lynas argues that such advertisements are discriminatory and could lead to unlimited compensation claims if challenged in an employment tribunal. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various personal characteristics, and employers must be able to demonstrate that physical appearance requirements are essential to the job.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and 19-year-old Sirisha, causing severe injuries. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until April 12. Gun crime in Indian schools and colleges is rare, but there are strict control laws and many disputes are settled with firearms.

The passage discusses a report by the advocacy group Glaad analyzing TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017. It highlights the increase in LGBT characters, with a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, it also mentions the high number of lesbian and bisexual female characters who died or were killed off. The report found a record high percentage of black characters, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledges progress but emphasizes that numbers are not the full story.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The opposition was reportedly due to millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC seemingly disappearing, with the loan subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. About £10.25 million of the money is missing, and the football stand remains half-built. A majority of his party's local executive council had planned to vote to deselect him. Mackintosh, who had initially intended to stand for re-election, later stated that he felt it was the right time for a new representative for his constituents.

A 37-year-old police officer, Roy Oliver, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards with a rifle as he drove away from a party in Balch Springs, Dallas. Oliver claimed self-defense, but footage contradicted his account. He is charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. The teenager was described as an exemplary player, son, teammate, and friend. Oliver faces 5 to 99 years in prison and could be the first officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. No trial date has been set, and he is currently free on bail.

The passage discusses the decision of Mrs. Trump to not reside in the White House during her husband's presidency, instead choosing for Barron to finish the school year before moving to Washington. The text explores the various ways in which First Ladies have coped with family arrangements in the White House, citing historical examples such as Martha Washington, Anna Harrison, Frances Folsom Cleveland, Dolley Madison, and others. It also touches upon the role of the First Lady, which is traditionally ceremonial but has evolved to include active involvement in public causes. The passage concludes by discussing the impact of the First Lady's role on the public's perception of the president and the personal lives of the First Families, highlighting instances where daughters have taken on some of their mothers' duties.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been tasked with investigating the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the Pirc's investigation and will await its findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) will receive a report on the Pirc's findings in due course.

The passage describes a yellow wind warning with gusts of up to 75 mph (120 kmph), particularly affecting the west of the mountains and having an unusual easterly direction. The forecast predicts disruption to travel on roads and at sea in the affected counties: Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight, strong winds caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road for cleanup work on Monday.

The Giants started with a player-coach, Derrick Walser, and Jeff Dimmen helped the Panthers level. Mike Forney's powerplay goal made it 2-1, which was later equalized by Andy Bohmback. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored, making the final score 4-2 in favor of Sheffield. The teams will meet again on Saturday for the second match of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, world champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back, faced a broken front wing, and did five pit stops. He finished in fourth place, while Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came in second. Kimi Raikkonen, also from Ferrari, finished fifth after recovering from an initial collision. The race was marked by numerous accidents on the first lap, leading to the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton's performance was hindered by damage to his car in an incident with Felipe Nasr's Sauber. Despite these challenges, Hamilton still faces a significant 36-point deficit to Mercedes' Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races of the season.

In an interview with Die Zeit, Thomas Hitzlsperger became the first prominent German footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality, aiming to advance the discussion on the topic. His announcement was met with praise from former teammates, such as Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as support from leading figures in German football administration, including Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. The announcement is seen as a significant moment in Germany, where homophobia in football has been a persistent issue. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, Steffen Seibert, also praised Hitzlsperger for his openness. The response from the football community and public figures indicates a growing willingness to discuss and support LGBTQ+ issues within the sport.

In this passage, it is mentioned that Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, contributing to Brighton's promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. His contract is set to expire at the end of the season, and he is now seeking a new deal to continue playing for the team. Brighton is currently in a strong position, with a four-point lead over second-placed Newcastle, and hopes to secure the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell previously played in the Premier League for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, and has made 19 appearances for Brighton on loan from Stoke during the 2015-16 season. He expressed his desire to stay with the team next year and believes he deserves the opportunity to play at the top level again.

The passage describes a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, which ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal by Jamille Matt. Colchester equalized from a corner in the 17th minute with a goal by Kurtis Guthrie. Blackpool had a chance to win the game in the 15th minute from a corner, but Tom Aldred's header was wide. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old football player, who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One, could make his debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Reid has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The passage discusses the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March, which led to a greater emphasis on the need for a permanent memorial for fallen officers. The UK Police Memorial Trust has appealed for £1.5 million to construct the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, with the names of over 1,400 officers and staff inscribed. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasizes the importance of creating a place to honor and commemorate the police service and provide a personal space for the families of fallen officers. The memorial, located in Alrewas, Staffordshire, will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. A brass screen with leaf shapes and personal memorials for the families of fallen officers will be included. The government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the memorial, and it is expected to be completed by 2019.

The passage discusses Manchester United's 1-0 win against Sunderland, maintaining their 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games left. Sir Alex Ferguson comments on the team's record of 25 wins out of the first 30 matches and their upcoming derby against Manchester City with a 15-point headstart. The focus is on winning the next game, and Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. Ferguson also mentions potential changes to the lineup, including the availability of Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez, and reflects on the team's performance against Sunderland, praising their determination and courage.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK, with former Google chairman Eric Schmidt stating that the company has complied with legal tax requirements and that any changes to tax laws should be made by the UK government. Schmidt argues that taxes are not optional and should be paid as legally required. He also suggests that if tax laws change, Google will adjust its tax payments accordingly. The passage also mentions the idea of a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms and the European Union's plan to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt advocates for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are conducted, and calls for international tax reform.

The passage discusses the efforts by the regulator, NHS Improvement, to reduce the agency bill in the NHS. The aim is to decrease the amount spent on agency staff from £3.6 billion last year to £2.6 billion by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October to prevent hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services from paying more than 55% above normal shift rates for staff, except for senior managers. The cap has saved £600 million so far. The regulator plans to publish league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust to address concerns about excessive pay for agency work.

The Longford Town Centre, a once bustling commercial hub, now stands as a symbol of the Republic of Ireland's economic downturn following the Celtic Tiger era. Despite the slow recovery, local businesses like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop have experienced a downturn, with a 30% drop in sales and the need to lay off staff. However, they have seen an improvement in business over the past year, partly due to diversifying into children's clothing and dress-hire services.

Fianna Fáil, the main opposition party, criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing that the investment in water meters should instead be used for broadband improvement. The party's local TD, Robert Troy, accuses the government of negligence and calls for a targeted approach to the area.

The government, however, defends its efforts, citing the upcoming Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, which is expected to employ about 1,000 people when it opens in 2019. Despite this, local businesses like Matt O'Brien believe more can be done to boost local commerce, such as removing parking charges to attract more visitors.

The passage describes an ongoing cricket tournament featuring eight teams, with the top four qualifying for the play-offs. The tournament concludes on May 29th in the same stadium. Leading run-scorers, highest scores in an innings, and most wickets are listed. Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage provides a detailed schedule of fixtures and results, including match times in BST.

The passage discusses the issue of plastic carrier bags and their environmental impact. It mentions that the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found the number of plastic carrier bags increased by 200 million since 2013. These bags are often not recyclable and end up in landfills and rivers, causing harm to the environment. To address this issue, from October, people in England will have to pay 5 p for plastic bags, hoping to encourage reusing the ones they already have. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where a charge for carrier bags is already in place, have seen a decrease in bags used. Campaigners are hopeful that the charge in England will reduce the amount of bags being thrown away, thus helping the environment.

The passage describes a day of severe weather in Wales, affecting various aspects of daily life. Key points include:

1. Part of a school roof being ripped off at Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd.
2. Hundreds of homes experiencing power cuts across Wales.
3. Train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges.
4. A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales until midnight on Friday.
5. The busy Christmas getaway and end of the working week coinciding with the severe weather.
6. Highest gusts of wind recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona, Anglesey.
7. Irish Ferries cancelling six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to adverse weather conditions.
8. Arriva Trains Wales warning of speed restrictions and possible delays for services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead.
9. The National Trust closing Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to high winds.
10. Winds easing into Friday evening, with restrictions lifted on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge.
11. A blustery forecast

The passage discusses Michael B. Jordan's excitement for a new film project, where he will reunite with director Ryan Coogler and work with actors Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan expressed his eagerness to play a different role and look forward to working with Coogler again. The film is set to be released in February 2018, alongside Jordan's previous roles in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o's role in Star Wars: The Force Awakens.

The passage discusses the restoration and renovation of Alexandra Palace, with a focus on the theatre and BBC studios. Founded in 1875, the theatre is set to host various performances, screenings, and events. The project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018, as part of a larger east wing restoration aiming to transform the palace into a cultural destination. The glazed east court will become a public space for exhibitions. The Heritage Lottery Fund contributes £18.8m, Haringey Council contributes £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust commits to raising £1m. The total cost of the east wing refurbishment is £26.6m. The theatre, unused for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery.

The passage discusses the career of former Manchester City player Sam Milner, who is 30 years old and has won 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the squad at two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner has expressed his support for the decision made and wishes Sam Allardyce and the rest of the team success in the future. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scoring his only international goal in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

A fire engulfed Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, but the whole family managed to escape thanks to their son David, who was the only one awake at the time and saw the flames. The fire was caused by rubbish burned in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. The family lost their pets, and their house is destroyed, but the community has supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike. David's quick action likely saved his mother and sister's lives.

The passage discusses the consideration of a £200 million offer for the Premier League club by an energy drinks giant. The club, West Ham, was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 in a deal valued at £105 million. They now own more than 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium in August. Sullivan mentioned last year that a minority shareholding might be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

The passage describes a fan-voted awards ceremony held in Los Angeles, featuring winners and highlights from the event. Key winners include The Fault in Our Stars for best movie, Shailene Woodley for best female performance, best shirtless performance for Zac Efron, Bradley Cooper for best male performance, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance, Meryl Streep for best villain, and Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne among others. The ceremony also included promotional content for upcoming summer blockbusters like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Ultron.

A 21-year-old player named Smith was loaned from Aberdeen to United in July and has scored five goals this season. He made his debut in 2012 for Aberdeen and has scored four times in 89 appearances. Jack Ross, the boss, considers Smith a brilliant acquisition for St Mirren, praising his maturity and potential to be a good fit in the attacking area.

The passage discusses Northumberland County Council's plan to address potholes and repair damaged drainage systems due to heavy rain. The council aims to fill 145 potholes per day over the next four months using its Jetpatcher machines, which are now operational due to warmer weather. Additionally, extra staff will clear debris from gutters as part of the repair efforts.

A summary of the passage would be: In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown work. They were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE) despite being informed of the previous night's reading. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes raised concerns about EnQuest's duty of care and ongoing health tests are being conducted. EnQuest took additional precautionary steps and advised the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) of the incident, although it was not reportable under the RIDDOR system. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety, and Unite union called for openness and transparency in safety incidents.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore has agreed to return a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari, which it bought for $650,000 in 2007, after discussions with the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision was made after the manager of the art dealer from whom ACM bought the sculpture admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ASI had submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 15.5 km north of Lucca, Italy, with its epicenter in Garfagnana, at 15:48 local time. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake caused phone line outages and power cuts in the Garfagnana area, prompting school evacuations and checks for damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a deadly 2009 quake in L'Aquila killing almost 300 people. Italy's National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) described the latest tremor as a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" classic earthquake for the area.

The passage describes a moment of excitement for Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, who had been doubtful about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. On September 8, 2016, he finally witnessed some results, with fruit still attached to the plant but not yet ripe enough to eat. Grant expressed his joy by saying, "I was literally jumping for joy."

The passage announces the delay of the release of the open world adventure game GTA V until 24 March, originally planned for 27 January. Rockstar justifies the delay by stating the game needs extra weeks for testing and polish. The company also announces online heists for consoles before PC, releases PC version screenshots with promises of enhanced details, and publishes minimum system requirements for the game. GTA V was the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1 billion in revenue in three days upon its release on 17 September 2013.

A 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting, which depicts a leper squint, was described as "quite extraordinary" by the judge, Ansel Krut. The artist, who has been shortlisted for the prize before, entered the competition because he was familiar with the subject matter and wanted to showcase a relatively small piece. The prize money will be used for materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards and has previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The daily Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit's offices were attacked in Istanbul, with no casualties reported. Four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building, causing a fire that was quickly extinguished by firefighters. Both papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, shattering windows and leaving numerous bullet casings. Police are currently investigating and searching for the assailants, with no group claiming responsibility.

The 24-year-old former Burton player, who spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He will officially join the Mariners on January 1st, marking Bignot's first signing for the club.

The passage discusses the potential for Arsene Wenger to be linked with the England national team manager's role, with Wenger himself focusing on his job at Arsenal. Wenger praises Gareth Southgate, the current interim manager of England, for his experience and observation skills. Southgate is set to lead England in a World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly against Spain, aiming to secure the permanent manager position. Wenger also mentions that young defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract by Arsenal, despite being linked with moves to Barcelona and Manchester City. Additionally, Wenger reveals that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will be sidelined for "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in the opening Premier League match against Liverpool.

The local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive into the incident, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

The passage discusses a long-running dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats operated by Seatruck, which was contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. The RMT union claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement that will resolve the issue, with contracted out services returning to Serco Northlink from next month. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. The new arrangements will see all crew members paid at least the minimum wage, and are subject to some financial and regulatory details being finalised.

A 64-year-old man, Ken Dickie, passed away in the hospital on May 14, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. A jury at Winchester Crown Court found him guilty of common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice. The trial revealed that Mrs. Mitchell and Mr. Dickie were in a down phase of their relationship when Mr. Mitchell visited his mother at the park. Later, Mr. Mitchell got intoxicated and had a confrontation with Mr. Dickie, which led to a fight. He pleaded guilty to the assault and later described it as a "tragic accident." Mrs. Mitchell and Mr. Mitchell will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter, passed away at the age of 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer. Known for hits like "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights," Temperton's work was praised by Michael Jackson, Nile Rodgers, and other notable artists. Born in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire, Temperton's songwriting ability was influenced by his father. He started his career in the 1970s with the band Heatwave and later worked with Michael Jackson on the album "Off The Wall" and the "Thriller" soundtrack. Temperton won a Grammy Award and was nominated for two Oscars. He was known for his low profile and was nicknamed "The Invisible Man."

The passage discusses the discovery of ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, by a team led by Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott. The research team includes members from the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's São Paulo and Belém. The findings consist of more than 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest for centuries. The purpose of these sites remains unclear, but they are thought to be sporadically used ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America or Stonehenge in Britain. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples reveals that the geoglyphs were likely not visible above the forest canopy, raising questions about their purpose. The research challenges the previous assumption that the Amazonian forests were pristine ecosystems before European arrival, suggesting that humans transformed the environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees. The team suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices.

In a tennis match at the Shanghai Masters, Australian player ranked 21st in the world, aged 21, defeated world number 29 Querrey with a score of 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes. Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, won the Japan Open and is nearing the top 10. He explained his subdued performance by stating he was tired and had not had great sleep. Kyrgios mentioned his success in Japan and the travel involved had affected his performance.

The passage discusses the call for the rollout of the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination for boys, as it protects against head and neck cancers, which are on the rise in younger people. The vaccine is already available for girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer. Charities, organizations, and experts are urging the Welsh government to take a progressive step and implement the vaccination for boys, despite the government's current wait for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation. In 2008, a vaccination program was introduced in schools, with 85% of girls in Wales having been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after briefly attending a school prom held in his honor. Jak, who documented his life and treatment on social media, had been posting updates on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey. The page gained more than 28,000 likes and documented his experiences, including his love for Rangers FC, meetings with former Ibrox stars, and his stay at hospitals. Jak's cancer spread throughout his body, and treatment was discontinued. In the days following the diagnosis, Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

The passage describes a match between Egypt and Uganda in a football tournament. Egypt won the game 1-0 with a goal scored by Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda's goal attempt by Joseph Ochaya was disallowed for offside. Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Ghana has already qualified for the quarter-finals. The match took place on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, with Egypt unable to break down Uganda's defense for long periods.

The Lancashire County Council has selected land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College, is also unoccupied. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail of these sites and one near the Concourse shopping center. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed to passengers in 1956. The council, which owns Glenburn Sports College, plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour under the partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. County Councillor John Fillis, Cabinet Member for Highways and Transport, described it as an "exciting step forward." The preferred location is large enough for future expansion, has good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town on October 9, 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without its own railway station.
The passage describes the discovery of plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on a Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman, of Kurdish origin, was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, also of Kurdish origin, later turned himself in to the authorities. The motive for the attack is unclear, and police are calling for witnesses to come forward.

The passage discusses a study conducted by the Cass Business School, the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, and based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The research found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but men are 25% more likely to get one. The study debunked the "reticent female" theory, where women avoided asking for more money, and found no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to being more wary of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The researchers took into account various factors such as the size of the employer, industry, whether the workers were parents, and their qualifications. The study suggested that there might be some element of pure discrimination against women, and that negotiating behavior among younger women may be changing.

The Oxford City Council has been unable to find a suitable new burial site for many years due to factors like size, ground conditions, water table, and covenants. Two existing cemeteries are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council is still exploring options but has run out of suitable land within Oxford. After the two remaining cemeteries are full, only reopening of family plots, use of a few reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from July 19 to 22 in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, offers an augmented reality app that provides visitors with online information, videos, and band interviews. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as an enhancement to the festival experience and a way for global audiences to engage with the event and its atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." The horse had no significant underlying health issues and had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Many Clouds had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. The cause of death is believed to be the rare haemorrhage, rather than a pre-existing condition like overheating.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in 2004, and later that year, Ayrton raped her in a garage while two others were asleep. Ayrton, now 34, denies the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely in a male prison, due to concerns about her risk to herself and attending court. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer and changed her name in 2012. She claimed she had not physically changed or medicated herself and that the victim had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's during the attack. Ayrton confessed to the rape in 2014 to a worker at a care home in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The Serbian doubles team lost to Brazilian Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares with a score of 6-4, 6-4 in Rio. This loss followed a day when Novak Djokovic was eliminated from the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro at Wimbledon. Despite a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July, where he lost to American Sam Querrey, Djokovic bounced back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes an event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US participate. They use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is set to defend his title and compete for the Claymore Trophy.

The passage discusses the return to play for Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player who suffered a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. Webb is currently in the pre-season stage of his recovery and is close to a return to the field. He plans to take his recovery week by week and has requested a delay in his return by a couple of weeks, as per the advice of his physiotherapists. Webb is set to return to play in the Six Nations in February, with his first game being against Ireland on February 7th. He has also renewed his national dual contract with both the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other regions to remain with his home region and club, where he made his debut in 2007. Webb expresses his desire to play for his country and is happy with the agreement reached between Wales and the Ospreys.

The passage describes an incident where US border agents intercepted an attempt to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. Two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, were apprehended after a brief confrontation, and a third individual, Kali Henifin, was arrested for planning to pick them up at the border. A fourth person, Ryan Lambert, was arrested for allegedly planning to drive the drugs and receive $11,000 for his involvement. The total weight of the ecstasy found in the backpacks was 58 lb (26 kg). All four individuals face charges related to drug possession, distribution, and conspiracy. The area near the border crossing is known for drug and firearm smuggling, making such prosecutions a significant part of the US attorney's practice in the Western District of Washington.

The NSPCC's Childline service counseled over 4,500 children with online abuse issues in the past year, a significant increase from 2011-12. The actual number of children affected is believed to be much higher. Online trolls cause misery and humiliation, impacting children as young as seven. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, warns that bullying can wreck young lives and calls for intervention from adults, parents, and teachers. The Anti-Bullying Week report, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, highlights the need for collaboration between parents, schools, and organizations to combat cyberbullying. A young person who contacted Childline shares their experience of being told to kill themselves online, emphasizing the difficulty in standing up to bullies and the importance of seeking help.

The passage discusses the decision by Israel to postpone a planned vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. This move comes ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry. The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Mr. Netanyahu. The resolution stated that the establishment of settlements "has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law and a major obstacle to the achievement of the two-state solution and a just, lasting and comprehensive peace." The passage also mentions the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the presence of over 500,000 Jews in 140 settlements since 1967, and the upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France on January 15.

The passage describes the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, including a BBC interview where Prince William paid tribute to her as a guiding example of a good monarch. The Queen's birthday was marked with various events, including a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, where she was welcomed by the Royal Mail choir and met staff. The royal family's portrait was released on stamps to mark the monarch's birthday. Prince William addressed recent criticisms about his commitment to royal duties, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but needs to develop into the role. The Queen's birthday celebrations included lighting a beacon, unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway, and a lunch with the Obama family at Windsor Castle.

The passage describes a football match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United in the EFL Cup. West Ham United won the match with a score of 2-0, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham Town had some close opportunities, including a volley by Harry Pell and a header by Jordon Forster. West Ham United made several changes to their lineup, while Cheltenham Town remained unchanged. The match concluded with West Ham United having a better performance and control over the game, leading to Cheltenham Town's exit from the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old from Leipzig, failed to spot the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000, with a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family saw no value in Werner receiving jail time, as they believed it was a momentary lapse and nothing could bring Aidan back.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, West London, is facing a possible prison term up to life imprisonment for his role in the conflict in Syria. He was one of the most public British fighters in Syria, always online but always masked. Khawaja, who left the UK in January 2014, was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State that spent over a year selling a message to their supporters and would-be recruits back home. He was involved in appeals for donations and producing propaganda videos. Khawaja's return to the UK last year was a risky move, as he faked his own death with an online obituary and tried to sneak back into the country unnoticed. He is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria and was held in the special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison.

The passage discusses the signing of 22-year-old Jackson, a forward who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, by Barnsley. Jackson, who turned down a contract offer from Wrexham, is seen as a fit for Barnsley's playstyle by caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom. This is Barnsley's third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

The passage describes the discovery of sealed detergent bottles washed up on beaches near Poldhu Cove, Lizard, and other nearby coves in Cornwall. The National Trust volunteers are clearing them to prevent harm to wildlife. The origin is believed to be a container that fell off a ship during stormy weather, possibly the MV Blue Ocean, which lost its container of 'Vanish' detergent in May. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there's no definitive evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this specific loss, with the evidence currently being circumstantial. The main concern is the potential impact on the marine environment due to the detergent content. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expresses concern over the effect on sensitive marine life. The National Trust, Cornwall Council, Maritime and Coastguard Agency, and Natural England are monitoring the situation and advising the public to keep a safe distance from any additional bottles that may wash up.

The passage describes an incident on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness that occurred around 2:00 PM, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries. The road was subsequently closed, and diversions were set up using the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently investigating the event.

The passage discusses Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back who made 14 appearances last season with Wanderers, helping them finish second in League One and secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite, who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contributions towards the end of the campaign, despite being a bit of a forgotten man. Dervite is the latest player to sign a new contract with Bolton, following David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage discusses the breakdown in cooperation between the Liberal Democrats and the Labour Party in the House of Lords, particularly concerning the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything," while Baroness Smith responded that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope." Despite their previous alliance to inflict defeats on the government, the cooperation ended when MPs rejected the amendments. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for building up false hope, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite having formed alliances on other issues in the past, there are tensions and a lack of demand for future collaboration.

The passage discusses the current state of defense priorities in the UK, with politicians largely ignoring defense as a key issue in the election. The UK's military capabilities are being reduced, with a decrease in the size of the regular army and the Royal Navy, and a lack of commitment to spend 2% of the nation's wealth on defense. The UK is falling behind in defense spending and is at risk of falling below the NATO threshold. The future of the Trident nuclear deterrent is uncertain, with different political parties proposing various solutions. The passage also highlights the potential issue of not having enough personnel to operate the new aircraft carriers, which could lead to a "hollow force" despite having advanced equipment.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona in 2013. Barcelona paid £48.6m for the player, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club has faced allegations that the actual cost of Neymar was much higher, considering additional fees such as signing-on fees, wages, agents' fees, and a recent tax payment. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating Barcelona, and the club has made a complimentary tax declaration to defend its reputation. The case's outcome is yet to be confirmed, and Neymar has contributed to Barcelona's success with seven league goals and three in Champions League matches this season.

A concise summary of the passage would be: A 27-year-old Michael Luciw from Nottingham was killed in a car crash when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family believes that retired people should undergo regular driving tests due to concerns about the safety of older drivers. They argue that the older one gets, the slower their reactions become, and that there should be a driving test with a driving instructor to accurately assess one's driving ability. Luciw's family also suggests that older drivers should undergo medical examinations. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause accidents, and that the current rules for drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years and report any medical conditions affecting their driving are sufficient. Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people being able to drive for as long as possible, as it allows them to maintain independence.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of implants used to treat incontinence, with many women experiencing severe side effects. The original review group quit in protest over a watered-down report, leading to an independent expert, Alison Britton, examining the final report. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, recommending a range of treatments and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government confirmed the recommendations would continue to be implemented, stating they did not have the power to ban the procedures.

In the passage, 23-year-old Laura Muir broke Paula Radcliffe's 25-year-old record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds in a 5K race. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken and acknowledged Muir's potential for winning world medals. She also mentioned that Muir's race met the criteria for a record-breaking attempt, despite concerns about drug testing. British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be ratified.

The passage describes the results of a show jumping event at the Rio Olympics, where Jung won gold on Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who was injured. Astier Nicolas won silver and Phillip Dutton bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after recovering from a fall and being placed in an induced coma just 10 months prior. Jonty Evans finished 9th.
