The passage also mentions an opportunity to meet and ride a mechanical horse, Henry, at Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics, and encourages readers to learn more about equestrian sports.

In a four-set match at Wimbledon, British tennis player Andy Murray defeated Italian opponent Fabio Fognini, winning 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray clinching the match at 20:57 BST. This victory marked Murray's 11th appearance in the last 16 of Wimbledon. He will play against French opponent Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Fellow British player Johanna Konta also reached the second week of the tournament for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari of Greece. Murray expressed that the match was tense and not the best tennis, but he managed to get through. He was pleased to finish the match in four sets and noted that the end of the match was affected by the fading light.

A concise summary of the passage would be: On October 6, 2014, a sudden death occurred at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, prompting paramedics and police to attend the scene. The court learned that alcohol was served past licensing hours, leading to the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and were fined £3,000 and £1,000, respectively. The judge expressed concern over O'Neill's "appalling record" and lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.

The passage is a summary of a speech by Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists party, where he launched the party's manifesto titled 'Real Partnership'. He emphasized the importance of partnership over domination and criticized the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. Nesbitt defended his comments and expressed confidence in his position, stating that if the UUP enters Stormont, they would prefer to do so with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin. The manifesto includes various policy proposals such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing infrastructure projects, and supporting the LGBT community. Nesbitt also highlighted the theme of the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption within Stormont.

The passage discusses a motion to be presented before the Northern Ireland assembly, which aims to grant pardons to men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales. The legislation, known as 'Turing's Law', after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing, will allow both posthumous pardons for those who have already died and allow living men convicted of such offenses to apply for a pardon. The motion is expected to contain provisions for both posthumous and living applicants. Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses. The goal is to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales, and to address past wrongs in the criminal justice system.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, beating Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and moving her to second on the British all-time list. This achievement also moved her to second on the Scottish all-time list. Muir's time was just behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon's winning time of 4:19.12. Muir is pleased with her achievement and holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She is training for the Olympics and hopes to secure a place for Great Britain in the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. Muir started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and plans to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm in a week. She balances her veterinary studies with her training and recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage provides a list of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" in terms of water quality.

The passage discusses the murder of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Soviet spy who defected to the UK in 2000, by Russian suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argues that the suspects had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko, and instead, the Russian state is likely the sponsor of the plot. Horwell suggests that the use of polonium-210 in the poisoning indicates Russian state involvement, but he emphasizes that this does not necessarily mean President Vladimir Putin was directly involved. Litvinenko's accusations against the FSB and personal attacks on Putin could have been motives for the murder. Horwell states that the suspects have left a trail of polonium and have no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. However, extradition attempts have failed, and the suspects remain in Russia. The inquiry into the case is adjourned until Friday.

The passage discusses the appointment of Steve Smith as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing the retiring Michael Clarke. Smith, at 26, is praised for his extraordinary talent and has already led the one-day side. David Warner, 28, is named as Smith's vice-captain, despite his past disciplinary issues. Both Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

The passage discusses the views of Mr. Farron, who was recently elected as the leader of the Liberal Party. He expressed his passion for LGBT-plus rights and prioritized defending equal marriage as the top agenda item. He also aimed to extend marital rights for transgender people. Despite voting against the Equality Bill in 2007, Mr. Farron clarified that he supports equality and is committed to LGBT-plus rights. He mentioned the spousal veto as an issue affecting transgender people's equal access to marriage and the Lib Dems' concerns about "protection of individual liberties" that led to their amendment and eventual vote against the bill.

The passage discusses the closure of a French-based drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, Newfoundland, by Sanofi in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, has now taken over the plant for its pharmaceutical production, with the intention of hiring many of the ex-Sanofi staff. The company is confident that the investment will have a "very positive" impact on the area. Newcastle City Council leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, views the announcement as "fantastic news" for Newcastle and the North East, enhancing the region's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare. Accord Healthcare is involved in the development, manufacturing, and distribution of over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries.

The passage discusses the departures of three senior staff members from a local authority: Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland. Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, views these departures as indicative of the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates more departures in the future. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

A concise summary of the passage would be: The English rider crashed at this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike. Initially, Martin announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing but has no plans to race on Hondas this year. He also skipped the North West 200 and the Ulster Grand Prix due to his teammate's crash and the bike's competitiveness concerns. The rider expresses interest in racing classics and oddball events.

The passage discusses the results of Nigeria's elections, where the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari was elected as the new president, defeating then-President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's loss was significant in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a concern for President-elect Buhari regarding oil production and revenue. The elections were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader, facing corruption allegations and failure to address the Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east.

The passage discusses a report by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accusing Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of contributing to the haze problem in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia through their involvement in the palm oil industry. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global market. The report claims Olam and Temasek could be unwittingly encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to the haze caused by Indonesian agriculture fires. Olam's CEO denies the allegations, stating the company has a strict compliance policy against burning, peat, and deforestation. The company has only recently released the names of its 14 suppliers. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, has dismissed the allegations, stating they support no-burn policies for land clearance and urge oil palm companies and plantation owners to do the same. The passage also mentions the troubled track record of the palm oil industry, which is one of the world's biggest industries but is often accused of unfair and illegal labor practices, defore

The passage describes the introduction of a new law in 2016 that allowed dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they were outdoors. In response to this law, a restaurant started serving puppy platters, which resembled a dog's dinner.

The passage discusses the fitness and potential return of three football players: Fernando Forestieri, David Nugent, and Jacob Butterfield. Forestieri, a forward, is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only played from the bench in the last two games. Nugent, a striker for Derby County, could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield due to a groin injury. Butterfield, a midfielder, is hoping for a recall after scoring a late leveller against Huddersfield from the bench.

The passage discusses the lifting of the YouTube ban in Pakistan, which was imposed in 2012 following the uploading of an offensive US-made film. Google, owning YouTube, launched a Pakistan-specific version, and the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the lifting of the ban, some activists demanded transparency in the deal between Google and the government. The Pakistan's ministry of information technology mentioned an online process for blocking access to offending material. However, a YouTube spokeswoman clarified that government requests for content removal would not automatically be granted, and such requests would be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report.

The passage discusses the ongoing conflict between Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and LFA boss Musa Bility. Bility claims that Scala, a Swiss-Italian, should withdraw from the upcoming presidential elections due to a potential conflict of interest. Scala, however, argues that there is no such provision in the Fifa regulations and that he only stepped down in the past due to the Swiss candidate being the incumbent president. Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The battle to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter takes place in 18 days. The election, voted on by Fifa's 209 members, will take place in Zurich, Switzerland.

A concise summary of the passage would be: Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road after a flashover explosion occurred in a paint-spraying area. A forensic search has been conducted, and it is believed that a build-up of toxic fumes, combined with an ignition source, caused the fire-ball effect. Significant progress has been made in the investigation, and the Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

The passage discusses the controversies surrounding Tunisia and Morocco's participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia faced expulsion after lodging complaints against the Caf, which was resolved with an apology. Morocco was initially banned from the tournament due to their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears, but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), reducing the fine imposed on Morocco's FA. Both countries eventually participated in the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage describes a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a football game at Etihad Stadium, resulting in City's forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho being sent off. Despite the incident, Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second dismissal this season, while Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for his involvement in the scuffle. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses the increasing prevalence of cancer in Wales and the need for early detection through screening programs. It mentions a pilot project in the Rhondda Valley aimed at identifying early signs of cancer in individuals who are not showing any symptoms or signs. The project is focusing on breast cancer, and the doctors' team is looking for any signs or symptoms. The passage also talks about a previous visit to Denmark to see diagnostic systems and the improvement of cancer screening in Denmark. It highlights the difficulty of diagnosing cancer in early stages and the need for a more accurate diagnostic system. The doctors' team refers the patients to a specialist clinic for further examination to get more information and improve the chances of a correct diagnosis. The passage mentions a 40% increase in breast cancer cases in the Rhondda Valley and the need for a more accurate diagnostic system. It discusses the development of a clinical trial in Castell-nedd Port Talbot as part of a pilot project by the Health Board of Abertawe Bro Morgannwg. The trial has been successful over the past 12 months, and the Health Board of Denmark has followed suit by implementing diagnostic units. The passage quotes Dr. Gareth Davies, the founder of the Cancer Awareness Wales,

In a cricket match at Old Trafford, England won the series against Pakistan with a big margin, setting up their second-largest win. England scored 589 runs and Pakistan was bowled out for 234 runs. Joe Root was named the man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's performance, calling it the most beautiful innings he's seen. Former England batsman, Geoffrey Boycott, praised England's teamwork and discipline. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment, stating that shot selection cost them the match.

The passage discusses the appointment of Warren Gatland as head coach of the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley named interim coach. Forwards coach McBryde is set to lead the team for the third time, following tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint assistant coaches to assist McBryde. Martyn Phillips, WRU chief executive, mentions discussions with various individuals about the summer tour, with hopes to confirm the full management team next week. Gareth Davies, WRU chairman and Lions' selection panel member, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions will benefit the national team, providing valuable opportunities for development and growth.

In a closely fought match, Hull City managed to secure a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending their six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin opened the scoring for Southampton in the 6th minute, but Hull's response came in the form of a goal by Robert Snodgrass and a header by Michael Dawson, both scored within two minutes of each other in the second half. Southampton pushed for an equalizer, but Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves. Snodgrass's tireless running and determination lifted the team and the fans, contributing to their unexpected win. The match also saw injuries to Hull's starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, and Southampton's Virgil van Dijk's header hitting the bar. The win for Hull puts them closer to safety, while Southampton will learn from the match to improve their future performances.

A motorcycle crash occurred at 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa, with a local motorcyclist killed. The tractor driver involved was uninjured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between Woodhall Spa's Tattershall Road junction and Horncastle's Jubilee Way junction. Lincolnshire Police have not released the deceased motorcyclist's details and are seeking witnesses to the collision.

The passage discusses the actions of Macedonian President Ivanov, who canceled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings ahead of early elections in June. His decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, leading to protests in Skopje. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of recordings suggesting vote-rigging and murder cover-ups. Opposition leader Zaev alleges government corruption, while the government accuses Zaev of destabilization.

The passage discusses the recent events surrounding Swansea City Football Club, including the sacking of Bob Bradley and the appointment of Curtis and Paul Williams as temporary managers for a match against Bournemouth. It mentions Swansea's interest in appointing Paul Clement as their new manager, with the club aiming to stabilize their position in the league. The passage also touches on the potential consequences of Swansea being relegated to the Championship, with Curtis expressing concerns about the club's ability to quickly return to the Premier League. The passage reflects on Swansea's rise to the Premier League in 2011 and the challenges faced since the departure of Michael Laudrup in 2014. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of the club's history and success to the players.

In a League One match, Dagenham & Redbridge faced a significant setback as they were relegated to the National League after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient. The match saw goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona giving Dagenham hope, but Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal sealed their fate. Dagenham, who reached the Football League in 2007, struggled with a poor goal difference and a significant increase in conceded goals this season. Leyton Orient, on the other hand, maintained their play-off hopes with the win, despite a nervous finish. Dagenham's manager John Still expressed concerns about the team's organization and discipline, while Leyton Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of winning games to secure a play-off spot.

The passage discusses Steven Gerrard's return to his former club, Liverpool, as a youth coach in February. Klopp, the current Liverpool manager, is pleased with the appointment, as Gerrard expresses his desire to become a manager in the future. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. He is working towards obtaining his UEFA A coaching license, which is necessary for managing in the Premier League.

The passage describes a football match where Morton secured a comfortable win against Alloa. Morton took the lead with a goal from McManus on the quarter-hour mark, and Forbes' deflected strike doubled their lead. Alloa responded with a goal by Kyle McAusland before half-time. Morton extended their lead with another goal by McManus and one by Denny Johnstone in the latter part of the match, securing a win for the hosts.

The passage discusses the findings of Ofsted inspections in Birmingham, revealing that three places were found in squalid conditions and subsequently closed down. These places were operating illegally, and the owners face potential jail time of up to 51 weeks. Ofsted and the government are concerned about the growing number of unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities, teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Ofsted has closed three such places in Birmingham and is investigating others. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, warns that these cases are likely to be the "tip of the iceberg" and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization. Any place teaching children for more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. The government is planning to fund a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools and is considering further regulation for places teaching more than 6 to 8 hours a week. The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools, and the consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes aims to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence" by using local botanicals and capturing the local flavor palette. The distillery's operation fits into a cowshed and is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was a heroine in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

A concise summary of the passage would be: In August 2013, Harry Whitlam was killed by Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, driving a vehicle on private land. Green was sentenced to 16 months and 2 weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and the family's desire for a return to happier times. The incident occurred when Green, under the influence, backed a tractor into Harry while he was in a restricted area of the farm. Health and Safety Executive (HSE) inspector Julian Franklin described Green's actions as "reckless."

The passage discusses the appeal of Luis Suarez, a Uruguayan footballer, against his four-month ban imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during a World Cup match in 2014. The independent body, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), partially upheld the ban but allowed Suarez to train and participate in friendly matches. Suarez's lawyers argued that the FIFA sanction was too severe, and Cas agreed that preventing him from training was excessive. Suarez can now train with Barcelona and participate in friendlies, but he still faces an eight-game ban in competitive international games and a competitive debut for Barcelona is likely to be postponed until October 26 against Real Madrid.

On 18th March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The winning duo trained hard for a week, running around an athletics track near their home. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Participants could be of any combination, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying another woman. Richard and Anna will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the changes in job roles and potential job losses at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) due to the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October. The government plans to replace the tax disc with an electronic system allowing for monthly direct debit payments. Stephen Hammond, a minister, reassures fears of job losses in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, stating that any reduction in the number of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business.

The passage discusses the stance of Hungary's government on its contentious laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, as well as the EU's reaction to these measures. Hungarian Minister for Regional Development, Csaba Szijjarto, asserts that Hungary will not backtrack on these laws, stating that they fall under national competence and should not be interfered with by the EU. He also mentions that Poland will veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and the higher education law, which critics argue could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University (CEU), founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have held protest rallies against these laws. The Hungarian government is under sustained pressure from European institutions to withdraw these laws, but so far has maintained its position.

The passage announces the casting of Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou in an animated version of the film. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the star will voice Mrs. Potts. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017 and begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The passage is about the death of journalist Adrian Gill, who was diagnosed with multiple cancers and had been undergoing chemotherapy. Gill was a prominent figure in journalism, known for his wit, writing, and intelligence. He was a columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993 and was described as "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill's final column, about coming to terms with his diagnosis, was published in the Sunday Times. He passed away suddenly, leaving a profound impact on his colleagues and the journalism community. Gill was also known for his controversial writing and had faced criticism and censorship for his work. Despite his dyslexia, Gill had a successful career as a writer, starting with art reviews and eventually working for Tatler and the Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a rapper and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was attacked in Ulan Bator, Mongolia, while performing in a red deel (Mongolian robe) embroidered with a traditional swastika symbol, which is not a hate symbol in his country. The alleged attack involved being hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. Sukhbaatar's father reported that his son was in a coma for about 10 days due to serious injuries to his brain. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but has called local press reports "distorted." The accused attacker has not been identified. The musician's lawyer insists that the suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, must be investigated according to Mongolian law, despite his status and immunity. The case is under investigation, and the suspect is not in detention due to the non-serious nature of the injury inflicted.

The passage describes a demonstration by the action group Plane Stupid on Monday against the airport's expansion plans. The campaigners were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of an aerodrome, and will appear in court on August 19. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, and the Metropolitan Police announced that security at the airport would be reviewed.

The passage describes a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire. Nick Selman of Glamorgan scored a mature 101 runs, his second first-class century, despite being dropped on eight in the first over. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles from Gloucestershire contributed to the regular wicket falls. Gloucestershire struggled, with Aneurin Donald's 36 runs being the next best contribution. Glamorgan led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Selman and Taylor discussed their performances, with Selman expressing his struggle as an opening batsman and Taylor highlighting the potential for the bowlers and his recent opportunities in T20 and red-ball cricket.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August for allegedly threatening to falsely report a crime and then ambush police officers on the Dee Estuary. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made while he was drunk and late at night. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. The court was informed that North Wales Police was concerned due to Hughes being on bail for firearms offenses, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line Crisis Centre provided confidential support and counseling to individuals experiencing difficulties.

In a cricket match, Surrey posted a score of 255-7 with a significant partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst. Yorkshire made a good start but lost key players like Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance, and Tim Bresnan. Surrey's captain Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes' performance, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment in not being good enough when it mattered.

The 56 ft converted trawler experienced flooding and radioed for help to Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST, 6 miles west of South Stack. A pump was unable to manage the water intake, prompting the RNLI lifeboat crew to provide a pump and tow the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses Scottish middle distance runner, Muir, who has decided to focus on her veterinary medicine studies and will not be participating in the Commonwealth Games in Australia next year due to her exams. Muir has recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. She expressed her disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but emphasized her commitment to her studies and hopes to compete in future events, including the World Indoor Championships in March.

In this football analysis, Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's current struggles and their chances of repeating last season's title challenge. He mentions that Liverpool is far from the level required for a title challenge and may have to settle for securing back-to-back seasons in the Champions League. Savage criticizes Brendan Rodgers' transfer market decisions, particularly in not buying the right strikers to fit his system. He highlights the lack of intensity, work rate, and runners from midfield to support the striker, as well as a drop in set-piece effectiveness. The defense is also seen as a weak link, lacking a leader and with Simon Mignolet not commanding his box enough. Savage suggests that Liverpool will need a significant improvement to compete against Chelsea, who are currently on a different level compared to the rest of the Premier League. Despite these issues, Savage believes Steven Gerrard still has something to offer and is an important player for Liverpool, showing great desire and determination to continue his career.

The £45m facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock and will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after the renowned writer, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid aims to "preserve" the William McIlvanney name in Kilmarnock due to the writer's passion for providing good education for young people. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," authored the Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, was an influential poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributed to political and sporting life in Scotland through columns and TV programs.

The passage describes an incident where an unexploded sea mine, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near the town of Gourock, close to the swimming pool. The area was evacuated, affecting three streets, and a wider safety advisory was issued for residents within 500 meters of the device. An exclusion zone was set up on the river and at sea, affecting small boat owners and Caledonian MacBrayne's ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, with no immediate danger to the community. Due to the deteriorating condition of the mine and uncertainty about the amount of explosive material it contained, it was decided to move it to a safer place before disposal. Inverclyde Council expressed gratitude to residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and safe evacuation procedures.

The passage discusses the funding cuts faced by various sports, including cycling, archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, in the UK. It highlights the reduced funding for cycling by over £4 million, the shock and criticism directed towards the decision to cut badminton's funding despite their success in Rio 2016, and the overall decrease in funding for Olympic and Paralympic sports from £347 million to £345 million. The passage also mentions the targets set for Team GB for Tokyo 2020, the government's commitment to funding for the Tokyo Games, and the criticism from sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball regarding the lack of interest in team sports and their performance development. The passage concludes with the announcement of new sports to be included in the Tokyo 2020 program, such as baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, and Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton, with funding yet to be confirmed.

The passage describes a planning decision in Bournemouth, where three Victorian hotels will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks at East Cliff. English Heritage opposed the development due to its scale in a conservation area, but the council voted in favor, citing its potential to boost tourism. The site will feature a 90-room hotel and two new buildings with 122 assisted-living apartments. The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The council received 246 letters in support of the plans, with 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objecting, arguing that the demolished buildings contributed to the area's historic character. English Heritage expressed concern that the development would cause severe harm to the conservation area.

A concise summary of the passage would be: 20-year-old Pte Matthew Boyd was off-duty in Brecon when he was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely. Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter, but Vallely will be sentenced on December 8th. Pte Boyd, a Royal Gibraltar Regiment member, was found unconscious and later died from his injuries. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, with Vallely dragging Boyd's body away before fleeing. Vallely was under the influence and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon." Det Supt David Guiney urged against resorting to violence during conflicts. A family tribute mourns Boyd, calling him loving, caring, and loyal, while expressing the pain and void created by the tragedy. The community's support is highlighted as the "strongest people" in Brecon.

The passage describes an error in the electoral process during a recent election in Barnet, where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list. This led to the departure of Andrew Travers, the chief executive, by mutual agreement. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council plans to present its findings to the General Functions Committee by the end of May. The Deputy Chief Executive, John Hooton, will temporarily take over Mr. Travers' responsibilities while longer term arrangements are made. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The error was attributed to problems with electoral registration lists, and the investigation will also look at the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

In a match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Josh Gillies scored the opening goal for Gateshead with a free-kick. Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton's set-piece. Gateshead secured the win in the second half with Ryan Bowman's header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improvement in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with the team's performance, particularly in the second half. The final score was Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway at the top and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage discusses the ambitious project by OneWeb and Airbus to build a global broadband network through a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially reaching over 2,000. The goal is to provide internet access, particularly to schools, worldwide. To achieve this, the project requires a significant change in satellite manufacturing, focusing on high volume and low cost. The first assembly line is established in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The first 10 satellites are set to launch in April of the following year, with more to follow. The constellation will be deployed using more than 20 Soyuz rockets, with over 800 satellites in orbit by the middle of the decade. OneWeb is not the only company planning a mega-constellation, but it believes it has a first-mover advantage. The company has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans to complete the roll-out. OneWeb CEO Eric Béranger emphasizes the importance of the UK in terms of economic growth and fostering an ecosystem. The UK Space Agency is concerned about debris mitigation, and OneWeb commits to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and

The passage discusses the financial challenges faced by the Scottish government due to the UK government's spending review, which imposes "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure. Scottish First Minister, Mr. Swinney, is set to present his 2016-17 spending plans, highlighting that the UK government has imposed real-terms cuts on Scotland every year until 2020, amounting to more than £1 billion still to come by the end of the decade. The Scottish government argues that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr. Swinney emphasizes that schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland will not be sacrificed to the UK Chancellor's austerity measures. In response, a UK government's Scotland Office spokesman points out that the Scottish government will have £390 million more in spending available to them next year, and that the stability of the UK economy provides a better deal for Scotland than the constitutional alternative favored by the Scottish government.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities, their families, and carers when accessing suitable toilet facilities. It highlights the need for more accessible toilets, particularly "Changing Places" toilets, which offer enhanced facilities for those requiring additional support. Although recommendations for such facilities exist in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities, campaigners argue for their compulsory implementation. The text also mentions the current number of Changing Places toilets in the UK, the need for more, and the psychological impact on families due to the lack of suitable facilities. The passage concludes by discussing the positive response from Arsenal Football Club after installing a Changing Places toilet, emphasizing the importance of accessibility for all customers.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's for allegedly forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. McDonald's argues that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, and the European Commission has received a submission to study the complaint, potentially leading to an investigation if the allegations are deemed founded. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to long contracts and lease premises at above-market rates, resulting in poorer consumer choice and higher prices compared to company-owned stores. McDonald's franchised restaurants accounted for 73% of its European outlets and generated $9.27 billion in revenues in 2014.

A 13-year-old boy from Donaghadee, County Down named Joshua Martin, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. He was due for an appendix operation but was instead found to have a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. In response to his diagnosis, a social media campaign supporting Joshua began with the hashtag #prayforjosh by Bangor Elim Church, where his father works. The campaign quickly went viral, receiving support from people all over the world. A mystery donor then paid for a billboard with the same hashtag to appear in Holywood, promoting global support for Joshua and his family.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in Brecon, Wales, which has been a military site since 1805 and has a long history of serving the country. Chris Davies, the MP for Brecon and Radnorshire, condemns the closure, stating it is an abhorrent decision and plans to fight it. He highlights the barracks' historical significance and the potential impact on the local economy and military tourism industry. Despite the closure, civilian and military staff are not at risk of losing their jobs. The reorganization in Wales will create a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, and Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in the following years. Nia Griffith, Shadow Defence Secretary, acknowledges the need for estate restructuring but warns that closing bases will affect the livelihoods of many people.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. It highlights the concerns of the House of Lords European Union Committee regarding the risks and opportunities for the industry post-Brexit. The report emphasizes the importance of not marginalizing the fishing industry in the wider Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has often been criticized by the UK fishing industry, and Brexit offers a chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the report also warns that Brexit may involve trade-offs, such as allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters in exchange for continued market access. The fishing industry's low priority for the government and the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in the UK's constituent nations are also discussed. Despite these concerns, many in the industry believe that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, and the recent agreement on new quotas under the CFP is seen as a positive sign for the future of British fishing outside the EU.

The passage discusses the revelations made by Ed Snowden, a former technical worker for the CIA, regarding the extent of US surveillance practices. Snowden revealed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to a wide range of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals. The NSA has also requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and the phone numbers of both parties on individual calls.

The passage also highlights the Prism program, which provides the NSA with "backdoor" access to the servers of major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, Skype, YouTube, and Apple. These companies have denied their involvement, and it is unclear how the Prism program works. NSA Director Keith Alexander claims that the surveillance operations have helped keep Americans secure, but critics argue that the access may be more akin to a "catflap" than a "backdoor."

The passage discusses the implications of these surveillance practices for data protection laws and privacy. It notes that different countries have varying data protection laws, but they typically regulate what data companies can hold, what they can do with it, and how long

The passage discusses the founding of OpenAI, a venture backed by notable figures and companies such as Tesla Motors, SpaceX, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The primary focus of OpenAI's research is to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity without financial obligations, aiming to address the potential threats and benefits of AI. The passage also mentions the concerns raised by Elon Musk, Stephen Hawking, and other experts regarding AI's potential impact on humanity. OpenAI's statement emphasizes the importance of AI being an extension of individual human wills and as evenly distributed as possible to ensure safety and liberty.

A concise summary of the passage would be: L/Bdr Parkinson, a man seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th. Despite having a brain injury that took his speech, he remains humorous and intelligent. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, raising money for military charities. Since carrying the torch, he has received thousands of requests on Facebook, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per page. His mother, Diane, has expressed amazement at the phenomenal support and friendship shown to her son.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, remaining unchanged after three years of increases. Household real median income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021 (£14,300). Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6% in 2011, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the US had reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

The passage discusses the extension of a 25-year-old cricketer's contract with Lancashire until 2019. He moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013. The player, Buttler, is an ODI short-format specialist known for scoring England's three fastest centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praises Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers in the game, highlighting his contribution to the team's victory in the T20 Blast competition last year and his valuable experience at the international level. Buttler, who plays in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders having until 23 January to express interest in them. No preservation proposals have been submitted, and final decisions are expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports both recycling and preservation options, such as creating a reef for reef and diving attractions, which could generate income through tourism. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for the frigates, aiming for the best financial return for the taxpayer. Originally designed as anti-submarine ships, the Type 22 frigates evolved into powerful surface combatants with advanced command, control, and communication systems, and a crew of about 280.

The passage describes the political and racial tensions in Fiji since 1987, leading to instability and international isolation. Key events include a coup in 1987, a series of constitutions, the 2000 coup led by George Speight, and a 2006 bloodless military takeover. These events negatively impacted the economy and Fiji's international reputation. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, which led to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and the reinstatement of Fiji in the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep segregation. Fiji's economy is diverse but struggles with trade and budget deficits, making it a large aid recipient.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, as mandated by the United Nations. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that despite facing challenges, including attacks on shipments, Syria is doing its best to adhere to the deadline. He mentioned that two shipments were sent to the Syrian coast, but one was intercepted by terrorist groups. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's recent condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which has led to the deaths of 246 people, including 73 children, in the last five days. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, stating that soldiers and security forces thwarted an attack by terrorist groups. The US has expressed concern that the UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons is falling behind schedule, with only about 4% of the stockpile (30 tonnes) having left the country so far. Russia has urged Syria to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March 1st, with a deadline set last year for all weapons to be destroyed by the end of June.

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 2013 Man Booker Prize, a prestigious literary award. The list includes six novels from authors of various nationalities, with Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" being the favorite to win according to William Hill bookmakers. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The shortlisted authors are Mukherjee, Jacobson, Smith, Ferris, Fowler, and Flanagan. The winners will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The passage also mentions the sales figures of the shortlisted novels and the debate over the criteria for the prize, including whether it should be awarded based on literary merit alone or for "readable" books.

A man, who is a celebrity with young children and whose spouse is also in the public eye, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court has decided to hear arguments about whether it should grant the appeal and determine if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of the man's alleged extra-marital activities, but he argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The celebrity had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person starting in 2009, which led to a three-way sexual encounter. The High Court judge initially refused to impose an injunction barring publication, but the man appealed, leading to a ruling in his favor. The man is now appealing this decision to the Supreme Court.

The Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was recently acquired for £345.5 million. The new owners plan to enhance parking facilities, alleviate traffic congestion, and improve the appearance of the units. Ernie White, the leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have discussed potential planning issues with the council. Paul Clarke, the director of investments at Crown Estates, highlighted the focus on addressing parking and congestion problems, as well as improving the quality of common areas and facilities to make Fosse Park more attractive.

A live-action remake of the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast" was due for release in Malaysia but has been held for review due to a "gay moment". The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) had approved the screening with a minor edit concerning the gay moment, but the film's release has been delayed. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, a Muslim-majority country, but the country's tourism minister has called the ban "ridiculous". The film has been granted a "P13 parental guidance classification", and a new release date has yet to be announced. Local cinema chains are offering refunds to customers who have purchased tickets in advance. The "exclusively gay moment" involves LeFou, the sidekick of the main antagonist Gaston, who struggles with his feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film in Malaysia has been met with criticism from netizens.

The passage discusses the issue of unlicensed House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) properties in Southampton City Council area, where landlords renting to more than three unrelated people are required to obtain a HMO license. The cost of obtaining a license is around £1,000, while the fine for not having one can be up to £20,000. The council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan highlights concerns of tenants living in poorly maintained properties and fear of eviction due to the lack of regulation. Mandatory licensing for HMOs is enforced in three designated areas: Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (introduced in 2013), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (introduced in 2015). The council has faced resistance from a minority of landlords but has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The passage discusses the political situation in Ireland following the election, where Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are the two main parties trying to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil supports a minority government but not a programme for government, while Fine Gael is open to forming a minority government. The main issue preventing an agreement is the water charges, with Fianna Fáil wanting to remove them immediately and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is proposed. The election results showed Fine Gael with 50 seats, Fianna Fáil with 44, Sinn Féin with 23, and the Labour Party with 7, resulting in no party having a majority and the failure to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a passenger ship traveling to Valencia from Mallorca, caught fire on one of its car decks, causing the blaze to quickly get out of control. The passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats, with at least three injured and one seriously hurt being taken to the hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire was unclear. Assistance was provided by several ships, including two passenger ferries. The passengers and crew were eventually rescued by the Puglia ferry and were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were requested to provide counseling at the port. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire damage, and it is owned by the Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione.

The passage discusses the issue of duplicate entries on the electoral register, with 38 MPs highlighting people, including students, claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. The Electoral Commission suggests that individual electoral registers should be better joined up to help identify duplicate entries. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% actually voting, the highest turnout since 1997. The surge in applications to register to vote was particularly noticeable in the days after Theresa May called the snap poll and in the days leading up to the 22 May deadline. The Electoral Commission calls for clearer information on registration sites and a potential verification function to reduce the number of duplicate applications. They also suggest that people registered in two seats should choose in advance which one they will vote in at future general elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, is believed to have killed himself at the age of 40. He faced numerous legal troubles off the field, including assault charges, and was serving a 30-year prison sentence. Phillips was accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, and a trial was initiated on Tuesday. His former coach, Tom Osborne, mentioned that Phillips had anger issues and couldn't overcome his personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behavior" at an event in Chester. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858, and Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the Mercian Regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, receives payment for his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Lance Corporal Derby XXX has also participated in events like switching on the Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

The passage describes a thrilling football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund, with Liverpool securing a 4-3 victory. The game was marked by intense emotion, drama, and excitement, with both teams displaying exceptional skill. Liverpool's manager, Jurgen Klopp, played a crucial role in motivating his team to overcome a 2-0 deficit and achieve a remarkable comeback. The match took place at Anfield, where the atmosphere was electric, with fans singing and cheering throughout the game. Liverpool's victory propels them closer to qualifying for the Champions League and has boosted their confidence for the upcoming semi-finals in the Europa League. The passage also highlights the strong connection between Klopp and his players, as well as the emotional significance of the match for both teams and their fans.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government officials discussed their plans for negotiations with the EU, involving Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. Mr. Davis stated that the UK government would keep these devolved administrations up-to-date and proposed holding monthly meetings to share analysis and information. Mr. Russell, however, called for greater clarity and transparency in the UK government's plans and emphasized the importance of the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government aims to overrule a High Court judgment on Article 50 triggering through an appeal to the Supreme Court, with the Scottish government planning to oppose this in court.

The passage describes a study conducted on 13 cloned sheep, including Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane, which are clones of Dolly the sheep. These sheep are being closely monitored and studied to determine if they age and stay healthy in a normal way, as there is concern about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" to the next generation. The study focuses on three co-morbidities most associated with aging: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study could have significant implications for the future of cloning.

In a concise summary, the passage discusses a horse race where Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes comfortably from Magical Memory and Comicas. Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden, won the Oaks Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Gosden's stablemate Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. Shutter Speed's race was challenging due to soft ground, but she is expected to improve on better ground. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may not run him in the Derby trial due to the short gap between the Dante Stakes and the Derby. Shutter Speed is set to compete in the Chantilly Oaks, and Gosden plans to rely on Enable and Coronet in the Epsom Oaks.

The passage discusses the fluctuations in the British pound's value against major currencies and the volatility index, which has reached levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The pound initially fell, recovered, and then fell again, with the Leave campaign arguing it retreated to March levels. The Remain campaign's chances have fallen, and the Leave camp is ahead in recent polls. Hedge funds are short-selling on expectations of further pound decline. The markets are on full Brexit alert, and worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU have led to significant falls in Asian stock markets. However, Nigel Farage, a Leave campaigner, argues that a weaker pound is beneficial for UK exporters and that the pound has strengthened since Brexit became a possibility.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots, after losing to Barrow in a game where Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Cowley acknowledged the tough journey for his part-time team, but remains positive about their prospects.

The passage discusses a proposed change in the planning system in Northern Ireland, which will shift responsibility for most planning decisions from the Planning Service to local councils starting from April 2015. Michael Corr, the creative director of PLACE, is optimistic about this move, calling it a "huge opportunity for the future" that will allow councils to develop their own community and development plans. However, Friends of the Earth express concerns about potential discrimination and a lack of transparency in the allocation of planning permissions. They argue that a strict code of conduct must be enforced and that it is crucial for the public to know who donates to Northern Ireland's political parties. Some local politicians are also opposed to the move, with some citing security concerns and others arguing that the £7,500 limit for declaring donations is largely irrelevant in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times by a reckless individual using an air weapon, resulting in severe injuries and the amputation of her back leg. The incident highlights the need for licensing of air guns, a measure opposed by a majority during a Scottish government consultation. Teenie's owner, Sarah Nisbett, is concerned about the potential harm to children in the area and calls for the person responsible to be found. The Scottish SPCA urges the government to implement licensing as a matter of urgency to prevent further harm to animals.

Christian Benteke, a 24-year-old Belgian international, has become Liverpool's second most expensive signing after they triggered a release clause in his contract with Aston Villa. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after signing from Genk in 2012. Liverpool, who sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m, have signed Benteke as their seventh summer signing. The club describes the deal as a "long-term contract." Liverpool struggled for goals last season and manager Brendan Rodgers believes Benteke will help revive the Reds' attack.

The passage discusses a study commissioned by Tablets for Schools, which found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. The study looked at a representative sample of 671 state and independent schools and found that tablets are now being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. The study also highlighted the rapid growth of tablet computers in the classroom and their use in 9% of schools, where an individual tablet device is provided for every pupil. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools. However, researchers could not establish a definitive connection between tablet use and improved academic results. Despite this, head teachers reported a positive impact of tablets, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement. Dr. Barbie Clarke, the study's head, believes that the role of technology in schools will continue to grow, and the type of device may change, but it will not disappear. The study also mentions a separate study that found touch-screen computers particularly helpful in helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read.

The passage describes an exhibition titled "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool, featuring 25 evocative photographs that capture the life of children over more than a century, from the 1880s to the 1990s. The photographs provide a social history of life in Liverpool through the decades, showcasing changes in children's lives and how special occasions were marked on the city's streets. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and shows the Rollo family dressed for a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. The exhibition also includes images of children working, such as a young maid for a well-to-do Liverpool family captured around 1900. The curator, Kay Jones, meticulously selected 25 images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections to represent the good and bad experiences of childhood. The exhibition is on display at the Museum of Liverpool until September 25.

The passage discusses two football transfers: Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, has left Barrow to join National League rivals by mutual consent and could face his old club on February 18th. Striker Keating, 21, has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and is subject to international clearance. Both players are seen as valuable additions to their respective teams, with Nicholson highlighting their potential impact. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

The passage describes the approval of new legislation in Bolivia that permits 12-year-olds to be contracted to work with parental authorization. The law also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The legislation was signed into law by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia work to supplement their family income, often facing harsh conditions. The government aims to eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia through this law. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) has expressed concern over the potential breach of international regulations on child labor due to the lower working age compared to their recommendations.

A 50-year-old woman experienced sudden nausea, aches, and chest pain, which she identified as potential heart attack symptoms online. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. The incident led her to write a blog post warning others to recognize heart attack symptoms and call emergency services.

The core pieces of information in the passage are:
1. The 50-year-old woman experienced symptoms that indicated a heart attack.
2. She identified her symptoms online and took aspirin before seeking medical help.
3. She visited a cardiologist who performed a procedure to unblock a 99% blocked artery.
4. The woman, who is a well-known actress, wrote a blog post warning others about the importance of recognizing heart attack symptoms and calling emergency services.

The concise summary of the passage covering the core pieces of information is:
A 50-year-old woman identified her symptoms as heart attack symptoms online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist who performed a procedure to unblock a 99% blocked artery. She then

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, when a fight broke out with a group of youths trying to gain entry. Che was later stabbed in an alleyway, and despite efforts, he was pronounced dead an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was stabbed and taken to a north London hospital, in stable condition. Che had been invited to the party, which was well-run with adults present. He was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two other youths, aged 15 and 16, have been arrested and bailed. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses the reorganization of cancer diagnosis processes in Wales, inspired by a fact-finding visit to Aarhus, Denmark. The Danish model of care introduced three routes for diagnosis and treatment, including fast-track routes for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis, improved survival rates, and a faster pace of catching up with European standards. The passage suggests that Wales can learn from Denmark's approach to better organization and collaboration between GPs and specialists in cancer diagnosis.

The passage describes the establishment of a new service in Powys to replace the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in the UK. This service will have the authority to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest estate agents who breach estate agent laws. Powys won a competitive bidding process to provide this service, which will receive £170,000 annually. People with complaints about estate agents will still contact their local authority's trading standards department, which will refer cases to Powys if Estate Agents Act violations are suspected. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, and hopes this initiative will open up opportunities for Powys to take on more contracts and external work in the future.

The passage discusses a plan by NHS Employers to reshape the healthcare workforce, particularly addressing the shortage of junior doctors and GPs in the National Health Service. The Nuffield Trust review highlighted examples of nurses and pharmacists stepping in for doctors and GPs, suggesting that such moves could be beneficial in covering for doctor shortages and adapting to the changing nature of care, which focuses more on managing long-term conditions. The report emphasized the need for more support from other health staff, but acknowledged that additional funding would be required. The plan has received mixed reactions; while some support increasing the skills of the workforce, others argue that it should not compromise the quality of training for doctors or reduce the number of doctors themselves. Unions warn against using this as a quick fix for the NHS's workforce shortages, citing the need for adequate funding for training courses.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place was closed due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The road closure, on the A36, was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the collision's cause. First bus services partially resumed but are working towards a full service for the evening commute, thanking the public and staff for their support and understanding.

The passage discusses the ongoing debate between NRW and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the potential impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW claims that the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die each year, while TLP disputes these claims, stating that they have no "clear scientific basis." NRW's figures are based on the "best available evidence" it received, but TLP argues that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating these figures. TLP's computer modeling estimates a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all fish species. UK government ministers are considering the findings of a six-month review of the viability of the scheme, and both the Welsh Government and the industry seek clarity on the UK government's position in the near future.

The passage announces the announcement by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster of the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The agri-food industry is crucial, providing almost 100,000 jobs. Northern Ireland's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomes the announcement, highlighting the importance of agri-food for export-led economic growth. However, she cautions that the new body may have implications for the work of other organizations, including her own department.

The passage describes a tree planting event organized by the Woodland Trust at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting members of the public to participate. The project aims to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in WW1. The Woodland Trust is creating four new woods across the UK as part of their most ambitious planting program, with the goal of planting millions of native UK trees to commemorate the war dead. The event is part of the trust's pledge, "We will stand for those who fell." The Brackfield Wood project will eventually become a wildlife-thriving area for people to walk, relax, and reflect, with carpets of wildflowers including iconic poppies.

In Harrogate, Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her novel "Someone Else's Skin," an emotionally powerful story about domestic violence and honor crime. The book was praised for its finely and tightly written narrative. Ann Cleeves, festival programming chair, noted the strong shortlist and highlighted Hilary's winning entry. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking female private investigator, and for founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers worldwide.

The passage discusses the return of New Zealand cricketer Mitch Santner to Worcestershire for the 2017 season after suffering a finger injury in his second game in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expresses regret over Santner's unlucky injury, which was a significant setback for the team's chances of qualifying. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin the team after the June's ICC Trophy in England. Santner expresses his eagerness to return and make up for the lost time, while the passage also mentions Worcestershire's signing of Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

A concise summary of the passage would be: Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi in Kiev. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, returned to a restaurant for a missing glove and later tried to claim his assets. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that Barry's death was likely a staged hit-and-run. Ganna, who was 19 years younger than Barry, initially claimed to be a teacher but was revealed to be a lap dancer and stripper. The case is still active in Ukraine, with Ganna denying involvement and the Ukrainian police having closed and relaunched the inquiry as a murder inquiry.

The passage is about Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Merseyside, who suffers from a serious illness since the age of three. After multiple treatments failed, his family was left with no option for treatment in the UK. They decided to seek experimental treatment in Seattle, America, which is unavailable in the UK. Charlie's mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed her gratitude towards an anonymous donor who paid for his treatment, making her "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed." The Fearns family is now awaiting the start of the T-Cell therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital.

The passage discusses the implementation of two-step verification for Apple's iCloud service, which requires users to enter a four-digit code after typing their username and password into a device they have not used before. This measure aims to prevent third-party software from infiltrating Apple's internet storage service. The process works by introducing an extra step after an account holder has typed their username and password into a device they have not used before. They are also required to enter a four-digit code that is either texted to a trusted mobile phone number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the person does not enter the code, they are refused access to iCloud and are blocked from making an iTunes, iBooks, or App Store purchase. The two-step verification system is now the default option for Apple's iCloud service.

The passage discusses potential deal for I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up, Jake "Jakey G" Wright, to acquire 20% stake in Billericay Football Club. The finer details of the deal are yet to be disclosed, but Wright is expected to become a club director. The club is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay FC was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed comfort in investing £10,000 a week in the club. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The passage discusses a BBC investigation into the working practices of Derbyshire company, Derbyshire's warehouse, and Mr. Ashley being asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers. Mr. Ashley has been invited by the Business, Innovation, and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook. The committee will be monitoring issues related to low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage.
