Mr. Wright's letter states that the BIS Committee meets in public at Westminster, and Mr. Ashley has not accepted any of the dates offered by the Committee Clerk. If no response is given, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request for a statement, and the company has previously committed to reviewing worker rights with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War" written by Ilya Yashin and other colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The report claims that Russian President Vladimir Putin waged war in Ukraine for his own ends, based on facts gathered since Crimea's annexation in 2014. The authors argue that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels. The report presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit being directed by Russian generals. It calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles. The opposition aims to donate to extend the initial print run of 2,000 copies, but faces challenges in publishing and distributing the dossier. Critics of Putin praise Nemtsov's reports for exposing corruption and the true cost of the Sochi Olympics, but they did not galvanize protests against him.

The passage describes the discovery of Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire, who died at the age of 34 due to head injuries. South Yorkshire Police arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in connection to the incident and are currently holding them in custody.

The passage discusses the concerns raised by Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, regarding the lack of consultation and respect for the devolved administrations in the drafting of the Article 50 letter by the UK government. Despite some common ground on free trade within the single market, Jones criticizes the UK government for not sharing the letter before its publication and not inviting input from the devolved administrations. The UK government's aim was to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but Jones argues that the process has been frustrating and lacking in respect.

The UK government mentioned Wales in the Article 50 letter, stating that they would consult on which powers should reside in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The letter also mentioned the expectation of the government that the outcome of the process would be an increase in decision-making power for the devolved administrations. However, the passage raises questions about which specific powers would be devolved and whether money would follow the powers. Alun Cairns, the Welsh Secretary, did not answer these questions, and Carwyn Jones expressed concern that there might not be any money accompanying the powers after 2020.

The passage describes an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night where two cars were damaged. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his appall at the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The police were carrying out their duties when they were attacked, as stated on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page. The post also appeals to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

The passage discusses the ousting of Mr. Charney, the founder of a company, due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The San Francisco court filing by the board stated that they did not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer argued that the statements made were false and accused the company of invading privacy and attempting to extort him. The court filing included evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts from Mr. Charney, which he had filed against in a defamation lawsuit. The company's papers claimed that Mr. Charney violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. The board added that it would be hard to find a board willing to hire Mr. Charney due to the risk to the company and its shareholders. Additionally, American Apparel recently granted a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball game between Great Britain and Greece, which will be broadcasted on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game will take place at the Copper Box in London and is a crucial warm-up for Great Britain's upcoming participation in the FIBA EuroBasket 2017. The European title contenders, Greece, won the previous match against Great Britain with a score of 92-64. Three members of the Greek team will be absent, giving Great Britain a chance for revenge. The game's atmosphere is expected to be exciting, and it will be the only home game for Great Britain before the EuroBasket tournament, which starts in Istanbul, Turkey, at the beginning of September. After the game, Great Britain's team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up games before EuroBasket. The game's broadcast schedule is from 17:30 to 19:30 on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website.

The passage recounts the author's experience witnessing the unveiling of the iPhone by Steve Jobs in 2007. The author was initially unable to get their hands on the new Apple phone but managed to borrow one from Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, to use in a news piece. The author reflects on the impact of the iPhone, noting how it transformed photography and various other activities, making powerful computers accessible to over two billion people and disrupting industries. The passage highlights the iPhone's role in kickstarting the mobile connected era and acknowledges the contributions of other companies like Amazon and Google in advancing innovation with AI-imbued products.

The passage describes a series of poisoning incidents involving cats in the Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire area near Victor Avenue. All affected cats have tested positive for ingesting a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen being the latest victim to die. The cause of the poisoning is unclear, whether accidental or deliberate. Three other cats have died in the last seven days, and another two weeks ago. The owner of Meereen discovered the cat foaming at the mouth and trying to vomit behind the sofa. The vet confirmed the cat had consumed antifreeze, which is a common antifreeze poisoning in this context. The RSPCA is investigating the incidents and urging caution, especially during the season when antifreeze is commonly used in cars. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is appealing for residents to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely to prevent further incidents.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is expected to agree and implement further austerity measures despite protests on the streets. Despite this, Greek resorts are teeming with visitors, likely due to the country's attractiveness compared to regions controlled by the Islamic State. The passage questions why Greeks are not protesting against announced austerity measures and criticizes the government for not delivering on promises to end fiscal austerity. It highlights the economic squeeze Greece is facing, with banks partially closed and no money to lend, which could lead to canceled Christmas shopping. The passage concludes that for the new bailout deal to be a path to genuine recovery, creditors must consider easing the burden of Greece's unsustainable debts.

In a brief return to EastEnders, Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell to bring the Mitchell family together for the emotional scenes surrounding the death of their mother, Peggy, from cancer. Kemp last played Grant in 2006, and his character will reappear after a 2010 departure to inform Phil (Steve McFadden) of her cancer's return. The storyline will culminate in Peggy's death in spring episodes, reuniting the Mitchell brothers for the final time. Grant Mitchell, a soap opera legend, has been involved in numerous family dramas, including affairs with his brother's wives. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlights the opportunity to showcase Kemp and McFadden at their best, particularly in the context of the brothers coming together to mourn their mother.

A concise summary of the passage would be: Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October. Her parents, Sue and Clive Ruggles, initially recognized the killer when two Northumbria Police officers informed them of their daughter's death. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice, and Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring her daughter that the police were aware of the situation and it would be okay to ignore him. The Ruggles have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking and to remember Alice for her vibrant personality. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project, which is being financed by French firm EDF and has Chinese investors contributing a third of the £18 billion cost, has been approved for funding by EDF's board. However, the UK government is now considering a further review of the project, following criticism over environmental damage, potential cost escalations, and the involvement of foreign governments. The power plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement and has been described as a "unique asset for French and British industries."

The new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with, which can add conflict and complexity to the process. Although the form states that naming the third party is not normally necessary, some people may still choose to do so. The inclusion of this field is seen as an invitation to name the third party, potentially leading to delays and increased costs in the court case. The Ministry of Justice states that there is no obligation to name the third party, and this information is relevant to divorce proceedings.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental and commercial forestry in Wales. Ministers are criticized for placing too much emphasis on the environment, while the timber industry, represented by Confor, argues that commercial forestry is essential for the economy. The UK currently imports the third-largest amount of wood, and the timber industry is worth over £450 million a year to the Welsh economy. However, there is a loss of commercial forest land since 2001, and the Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development. The Glastir scheme encourages farmers to plant woodland, and the Woodlands for Wales forestry strategy aims to enhance the landscape, provide social benefits, and support woodland-based industries. Confor's Martin Bishop believes that the focus on environmental aspects is seen as more appealing and that the current system is bureaucratic, hindering the creation of new woodland areas.

The passage describes an incident where a boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. The event occurred on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40. Emergency services were called to the scene, and the boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported to be serious.

The passage recounts the presentation of Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys by Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. The Arctic Convoys were vessels that transported supplies from Britain to northern Russia during World War II, facing constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe cold, storms, and ice floes. The ceremony was a recognition of the veterans' bravery and the vital role they played in supplying the Soviet Union, which in turn helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The Foreign Office initially opposed the awarding of foreign medals, but an exception was made, allowing the veterans to receive the Ushakov medals.

The passage discusses the findings of an HM Inspectorate of Probation report regarding delays in getting offenders to start their work and the issue of many offenders not attending their community payback hours. In one case, an offender completed just 16 hours in 17 months. The report outlines 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the frequency of offenders being turned away from work and creating objectives for unpaid work that match the circumstances of the offender. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the report's recommendations and is taking action to implement them.

A comedian, who campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, has been accused of hypocrisy by a newspaper. The paper highlighted his luxurious lifestyle, living in a spacious London home, while he claims to speak up for the poor. The comedian was asked about his accommodation by a TV reporter and became upset with the question, calling the journalist "a snide" before walking off. The comedian has been accused of hypocrisy before, but has defended himself by saying that "revolution is change," and he believes in personal and systemic change.

The passage discusses the life and achievements of Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur known for his contributions to the field of human genomics and synthetic biology. Born in 1946, Venter initially struggled academically but later became inspired by his experiences in the Vietnam conflict to pursue a career in medicine. He excelled in research during his medical training and, in the early 1980s, began working at the US National Institute of Health, where he recognized the importance of decoding genes.

Venter's breakthrough came when he realized that focusing on messenger RNA molecules rather than the entire genome could speed up gene sequencing. This led to unprecedented rates of gene sequence production and sparked controversy, particularly with co-discoverer of DNA, James Watson, who dismissed the results as work that could be done by a monkey.

In 1992, Venter left the NIH and established the Institute for Genomic Research, later forming Celera Genomics in 1995. This company aimed to complete the human genome project in three years, outpacing the public project. Venter's innovative approach and success in the field earned him significant financial rewards, allowing

The passage discusses a survey conducted on parents in England about their children's school lunches. The key findings include: 
1. Four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school.
2. Half of the parents surveyed wanted to cook school lunches at home.
3. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less popular.
4. The survey involved 628 parents with children who ate school lunches.
5. School meals can help encourage children to try new foods and increase their diet's variety.
6. Mumsnet co-founder believes that school meals, with peer pressure, can help children eat a wider variety of foods.
7. School meals in England now comply with strict nutritional guidelines.
8. About 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, slightly more than secondary school children.
9. The survey was conducted online among parents with children aged 4-17.

The passage discusses Spanish footballer Alvaro Morata's career, focusing on his move from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014, his current participation in Euro 2016, and his impressive goal-scoring record. Morata, who is 23 years old and 6 ft 3 in height, has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He has also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, including a substitute appearance in Real Madrid's 2014 win and a goal in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Morata's transfer to Juventus included an option for Real Madrid to buy him back at a reported fee of up to 30 million euros.

The passage discusses the return of Wilson to Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013. It mentions that he has been without a team since being released in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances during his second spell at the City Ground and previously spent four seasons at the club before signing for Celtic. Wilson has also had stints with Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant Tesco has sold its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business £80m and will dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand for £150m, with part of the cost being a potential loan repayment. The remaining 50 stores will be closed. Yucaipa plans to focus on supermarket and restaurant businesses and is run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse in their sport but overcame it. Initially considering representing France, they have now shifted their focus to achieving a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The text also mentions an interest in learning about getting into martial arts.

1. What was the initial challenge the individual faced?
2. How did they overcome it?
3. Initially, which country did they consider representing?
4. What is their current goal?
5. What is the additional information provided about the text?

1. The initial challenge the individual faced was racial abuse.
2. They overcame it by focusing on their sport and goal.
3. Initially, they considered representing France.
4. Their current goal is to achieve a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.
5. The additional information provided is a reference to a special guide on how to get into martial arts.
The answer is: 2016 Rio Olympics1. What was the initial challenge the individual faced?
2. How did they overcome it?
3. Initially, which country did they consider representing?
4.

The passage discusses the significant retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past four decades, from an area of 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting and was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie. They used manual inspection to verify satellite data and assessed the area of roughly 600 glaciers in various massifs, including the Mont Blanc Massif. The average loss of ice area over the last 40 years is about 26%, with the greatest losses occurring in the southern sectors. The retreat is less significant in the northern Alps due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions. The efforts to monitor and assess glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region, with similar findings of accelerating mass loss in the Swiss Alps.

The passage discusses the Scottish Women's national football team's strong performance in qualifiers, currently undefeated, and their upcoming match against Iceland. Captain Lisa Evans expresses the team's determination to avoid the heartbreak of missing out on major competitions, having fallen short twice in the past. The outcome of the match against Iceland could determine who tops the group, with the best six of the eight group runners-up also qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands.

Evans highlights the importance of the match, noting that despite Iceland being the top seeds, the Scottish team has a good chance of winning. The team's current squad includes 12 players who play outside Scotland, with some in English clubs, Sweden, and the United States National Women's Soccer League. Evans shares her experience playing in the German Bundesliga, where she won the women's league in her first season, and her interactions with the men's team at Bayern Munich.

Evans believes that having more players in top international leagues, like the German Bundesliga, benefits the national team by introducing new playing styles and competition, which helps improve the overall quality of the team.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London alleging harassment over two years. Campbell, who was released on bail, insisted the allegations concerned his tweets, which he claims were not threatening. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation of online harassment. Campbell has been bailed to a date in mid-September and has accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation.

The passage discusses the proposal by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) to replace the mascot Jolly Fisherman of Skegness with a modern, animal-friendly version. PETA suggests a fish mascot with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes all suggestions but doubts there would be much support for removing Jolly. The Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908, has become synonymous with Skegness. PETA's Dawn Carr argues that Jolly evokes images of animal cruelty, and the group's suggestion would allow Skegness to rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination. Mayor Macey defends Jolly, stating it is loved by adults and children and does not represent animal cruelty. The proposal will be considered by the council, but Macey suggests not altering Jolly if it doesn't need fixing.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland dominated the game, scoring six tries while Georgia managed only two. Key moments included Tommy Seymour's early try, a penalty try awarded to Scotland, and Stuart Hogg's try. Georgia's only two tries came from Vasil Lobzhanidze and a scrum-caused penalty try. Scotland's strong performance was highlighted by their possession and territory advantage, leading to a final score of 38-11 in favor of Scotland.

The passage describes a rugby match between Widnes and Castleford, where Widnes emerged victorious with a final score of 38-12. Key players for Widnes included Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, and Joe Mellor, who contributed to their significant lead. Castleford managed to score three tries in the second half, led by Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Paddy Flynn, who scored a hat-trick. Despite Castleford's efforts, Widnes held on to secure the win. The match had a significant impact on the teams' standings, with Widnes moving above Wakefield into seventh place and Castleford remaining in sixth place, one point ahead of the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee at the US military base in Guantanamo Bay, has been released after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been held at the facility since 2002, following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. Odah, who had challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court, is expected to face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait as part of his release terms. His release marks the first since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

The passage describes the Anzac Day commemorations held in London, focusing on the early morning service and parade at Hyde Park Corner, which included wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The event featured a service at Westminster Abbey, the singing of national anthems of Australia and New Zealand, and addresses by high officials. The first Anzac Day commemoration in London occurred in 1916, and since then, it has become an important occasion for expatriates and visitors from Australia and New Zealand to honor the sacrifices made by their countrymen and women in all wars. The ceremony included participants from veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families. The Gallipoli campaign, a key event commemorated on Anzac Day, was a bloody eight-month campaign in Turkey during World War One.

The passage discusses 30-year-old footballer Clarkson joining St Mirren for a second spell in July. He is expected to make his debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. Clarkson, who scored nine goals at Dundee last season, has mainly been a substitute this term. He expresses his readiness for the game, maintaining his fitness through U20 games and training. With two Scotland caps and one international goal, Clarkson has over 400 senior club appearances. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of the bottom. Clarkson looks forward to contributing to the team's success and pushing the club up the table.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was sold to Ranjit Boparan, the food tycoon, on Tuesday. There were concerns about the new owners honoring the workers' pension scheme. However, after productive talks with Unite regional officer Steve Harley, it was guaranteed that all current agreements would be honored. The final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and the current members have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan's Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Mr. Harley met with Boparan representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters and expressed the new owner's intention to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable position through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken alongside turkeys.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to discuss the issues surrounding the new vessel at Cowes. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July to acknowledge the problems and allow feedback. The council has ordered an auditor's review of the project, which has had a frustrating and disappointing start due to breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concern over the potential loss of six months of trade for local businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation for local businesses is up for discussion, considering it a prototype with teething problems. He added that the council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to address vehicle scraping the concrete, and seamanship issues have been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. It highlights the concerns of the House of Lords European Union Committee regarding the risks and opportunities for the industry post-Brexit. The report emphasizes that the industry might be a low priority for the government but should not be marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is often criticized by the UK fishing industry, and Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the report also warns that Brexit may lead to EU member states demanding more access to UK waters in return for continued rights to sell fish to the European market. The report suggests that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas are based on scientific advice. The potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland is also discussed. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry believe that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, and the recent agreement on new quotas under the CFP is seen as a positive sign for the future of British fishing outside the EU.

Timothy Geaney admitted to possessing or allowing child sexual exploitation images between 2004 and 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching register due to his involvement in an industry that abuses children, his conduct being fundamentally incompatible with being a teacher, and his failure to uphold professional standards. The panel found a strong likelihood of the offending behavior recurring due to the volume of images and the duration of the conduct. Geaney was prohibited from re-registering for two years.

A fire on 2 March on Duncan Street led to several days of firefighter presence at the site, impacting train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire. Although the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, giving the company until 7 August to appeal. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, had been visited by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service nine times in the last 12 months. The EA's decision was based on joint visits with fire safety officers and concerns raised by the fire service about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, as mandated by the United Nations. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to adhere to the deadline, despite facing challenges such as attacks on shipments en route to the coast for removal by ship. He mentioned that two shipments were sent to the Syrian coast, but one was intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's recent condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which has led to the deaths of 246 people, including 73 children, in the last five days. The Syrian government denies the capture of Aleppo's central prison by rebels and accuses the US of still supporting terrorist elements in the country. The OPCW has admitted that the destruction process has been slowed down by security concerns, but Mekdad reassures that Syria is committed to its agreements and will fulfill its obligations on time.

In a cricket match, England won against Pakistan with a day to spare at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, resulting in their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named the man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second innings. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's performance, calling it the most beautiful innings he's seen. Pakistan's performance was criticized for their lack of spirit and shot selection, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review to assess the quality of life and care for older people in residential care across Wales. She plans to gather testimonies from pensioners and their families to understand their experiences and develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be part of the discussion. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care experiences, with the ultimate goal of ensuring that older people in residential care have the best quality of life.

The passage discusses the appointment of Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder, as the new player-manager at Aberdeen's rival club, the Red Lichties. He replaces Neil Cooper and has been with Arbroath since 2010. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two in the 2013-14 season, Aberdeen CEO Duncan Fraser announced Sheerin's selection after a thorough process led by boss Derek McInnes. Sheerin, who has experience playing for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. His most notable achievement was guiding Arbroath to their first national trophy in 2011 by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion.

The passage discusses the recent events surrounding Swansea City Football Club, including the sacking of Bob Bradley and the appointment of Curtis and Paul Williams as temporary managers for a match against Bournemouth. It mentions the club's desire to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. The passage also touches on the potential consequences of Swansea City being relegated to the Championship, with the possibility of it being difficult for them to return to the Premier League. Curtis expresses concerns about the club's recent management changes and the loss of their unique playing style, known as the "Swansea Way." He believes the current squad is good enough to stay in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of staying up for the club and the local community.

The passage discusses the life and achievements of Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur known for his work in human genomics and the creation of a synthetic life form. Born in 1946, Venter initially struggled academically but later became inspired by his experiences in the Vietnam conflict to pursue a career in medicine. He excelled in research during his medical training and, in the early 1980s, began working at the US National Institute of Health, where he recognized the importance of decoding genes. Venter's breakthrough came when he focused on messenger molecules (RNA) rather than the entire genome, allowing him to rapidly sequence genes.

In 1992, he left the NIH and established the Institute for Genomic Research, followed by the commercial company Celera Genomics in 1995. Venter's approach to mapping the human genome was competitive and led to criticism from the scientific community, including James Watson. Despite this, his work sped up the entire process and eventually resulted in the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995.

In 2006, Venter founded the J Craig V

The passage discusses the findings of a study by the Sutton Trust, which highlights the low quality and short duration of apprenticeships in the UK compared to other European countries. The report suggests that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England each year are at level three, equivalent to an A-level. It also notes that only 61,000 new apprenticeship starts were for young people, while in Germany, 570,000 new apprenticeships are for youngsters, with 90% equivalent to A-levels. The study calls for the expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, focusing on level three or higher apprenticeships for at least three years, and no more than 10% two-year level two courses. The Department for Education has been reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, with over a million people becoming apprentices since 2010.

The passage describes British Paralympian Victoria Storey's victory in a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. It mentions that Storey can win her 17th title in the upcoming road race. She is the most decorated female Paralyquist with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze. Storey, who is aiming for success in the 2016 Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro, began her career in swimming before switching to cycling in 2005.

The passage discusses the financial struggles of Hereford United Football Club, leading to their expulsion from the Conference Premier League. Key points include the club's failure to meet financial deadlines, the extension of the payment deadline multiple times, the involvement of Hereford United Supporters' Trust in offering to buy the club, and the eventual takeover by London businessman Tommy Agombar. The passage also mentions the impact of Hereford's relegation from the Football League in 2012 and the decline in average attendance at their home games.

The passage discusses the career of former Manchester City player Sam Milner, who is 30 years old and has won 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the squad at two World Cups and two European Championships, but played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner has expressed his support for the decision made and wishes Sam Allardyce and the team success in the future. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scoring his only international goal in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a several-month illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it across six continents for over 30 years, producing over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His most famous recording, the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and held positions as a keyboard player, musicologist, and artistic director of various prestigious institutions. He was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. Known for his generosity and dedication to historically informed music, Hogwood left a lasting legacy on the music world.

The passage describes the struggles of a family from Northern Ireland, where the boy, due to his special needs, is not coping in mainstream schooling and is yet to be admitted to a special school. His mother had to quit her job to look after him. Despite the family's request, all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full, and no time frame is provided for a place to become available. However, a local special school has employed an extra classroom assistant, and the family hopes the boy can start there soon. The mother is concerned about the overcrowding in special needs schools and the Education Authority's inability to comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland and aims to ensure places are available close to where the children reside.

The passage discusses a potential takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) to acquire Newport Gwent Dragons, a fellow tenant at Rodney Parade stadium. The WRU aims to use the venue primarily for rugby events. The County, who have a lease agreement to use the stadium until 2023, are concerned about their rights and the potential installation of an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. The WRU's takeover bid will be put to a vote on May 9th. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey reassures that both the County and the Newport Squash Club, also based at Rodney Parade, are protected under their current agreements. The County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two and securing their Football League status is crucial for the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the life story of a former child soldier who participated in the Sierra Leone Civil War from 1991 to 2002. The individual was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels and underwent training in the jungle. They were subjected to threats of violence if they tried to escape and were forced to use drugs like marijuana and cocaine. Eventually, they escaped and found refuge in a home for former rebels, Lifeline Nehemiah, where they were mentored by Richard Cole.

After Richard Cole's death in 2006, the individual continued to work towards rebuilding the nation and contributing to its future. During the 2014 Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, they played a crucial role in setting up an Ebola treatment unit, which saved many lives. They educated over 10,000 people about the virus, provided support to over 11,000 people, and collaborated with other agencies to create an Ebola treatment unit.

The individual now sees themselves as a changed person, regretting their past actions and focusing on investing in young people to build a better future for Sierra Leone and the world. The passage also provides

Around 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs were set to be auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign managed to raise the necessary funds in just a month, saving the collection from being sold. The collection will remain at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be loaned to the Victoria and Albert Museum after being gifted by The Art Fund.

The passage discusses potential deal for I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up Andrew Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Football Club, with finer points yet to be disclosed. Wright, 30, is expected to become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. The team signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The summary of the passage is: The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead with a goal by Jamille Matt after 12 minutes. Colchester United equalized from a corner kick in the 17th minute. Blackpool had a chance to win the game, but Tom Aldred's header went wide. Colchester United player Sean Murray was shown a red card for a bad tackle in injury time, reducing them to 10 men.

The Fawley power station chimney, after being decommissioned in 2013, is set to become the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard as part of a £1 billion development called Fawley Waterside. The site, which was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, will feature a "merchant city" with a petal-shaped glass structure at its center, a marina, housing, and restaurants. Fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth are also included. The development plans also include preserving the chimney as a signature piece of infrastructure. Building could start in 2018, with an outline planning permission application due later in the year.

The passage discusses the achievements of British cyclists at the Hong Kong championships. It highlights the bronze medal win by 23-year-old Latham in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver medal in the women's scratch race. Latham managed to catch up with the gold and silver medalists, Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Lucass Liss of Germany, respectively. In the men's team pursuit, GB came in third place, beaten by Italy. The passage also mentions the performance of other British cyclists, including Joe Truman's elimination in the men's keirin semi-final and the fifth-place finish in the women's team pursuit heats by the GB team.

In a brief return to EastEnders, Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell to reunite the Mitchell family for the emotional scenes surrounding the death of their mother, Peggy, from cancer. Kemp's character, who first arrived in the show in 1990, will be reunited with his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, for Peggy's final episodes. The storyline was revealed when Peggy, who left in 2010, returned to inform Phil that her cancer had returned. The emotional scenes are set to be screened in the spring.

In a match against Liverpool, Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession, leading to Tottenham Hotspur's disappointment at Anfield. Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized the team's performance, stating it was difficult to fight for the Premier League with such a lack of desire. Spurs have only won twice on the road since September, and Pochettino believes they cannot cope with the pressure against top-six teams. Former Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized the team's performance, noting a lack of pace and a different mindset away from home.

The passage discusses the results of the Nigerian elections, focusing on the significant victory of the All Progressives Congress (APC), led by Muhammadu Buhari, who won the presidential poll and will be inaugurated on May 29. The APC secured 19 of the 28 governor positions, marking the first defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) in a key northern state and losing control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC failed to win in Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential disruptions to oil production and revenue. The PDP is expected to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader, facing allegations of corruption and inaction against the Islamist-led insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from July 19 to 22 in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, will offer visitors an augmented reality app that triggers online information, videos, and band interviews. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app will enhance the festival experience and allow global interaction, with updates on interviews, ticket purchasing, and festival atmosphere.

The passage discusses the Ofsted inspections of several schools in Birmingham, including Park View and Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, which were all rated inadequate. The Birmingham City Council is considering terminating the funding agreements for these academies due to concerns about their management and curriculum. The education minister, Lord Nash, has written letters to the chairmen of the Park View and Oldknow Academy Trusts, expressing deep concerns and setting out demands for improvement. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools, and the future of the schools after funding termination would be decided by the Secretary of State. The Ofsted report for Park View School criticized the academy's work to keep students safe from extremism and the school's failure to properly vet external speakers. Parents have criticized the Ofsted reports and accused inspectors of bias.

In July 2012, Vinnie, a patient of eye specialist Honey Rose, died after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal," leading to Vinnie's death due to a build-up of fluid in his brain. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into engaging in sexual activity and sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was also convicted of causing distress to the victim's sister and father by sending sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge stated that Weatherhogg posed a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

In a T20 cricket match, Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, but it wasn't enough to win against Afghanistan, who scored 171-4. Opener Stuart Thompson scored 56 runs for Ireland, while Gary Wilson and William Porterfield contributed 41 and 39 runs respectively. Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad led Afghanistan to victory with scores of 56 and 47 runs each. The second T20 match will be held at the same venue on Friday. Ireland lost early when opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck, and later with the ball, despite a strong batting performance. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the only bowler to take more than one wicket on the day. Ireland captain William Porterfield mentioned that they could have scored 15 more runs to reach their target of 180. The loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was another setback for Ireland. Rankin is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on March 15.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona in 2013. Barcelona paid £48.6m for the player, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club has been accused of the actual cost being far greater due to other contracts and additional payments. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crime and has made a complimentary tax declaration, although there has been no confirmation if the case will be dropped after this. Neymar has contributed to the team's performance, scoring seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

A concise summary of the passage would be: The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK and Thai police are investigating the murders, with two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both aged 21, who allegedly confessed to the crimes. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. UK detectives are working with Thai police to review the investigation and provide an update to the families of the victims. However, there have been concerns about the verification of DNA samples and the treatment of the suspects.

The passage discusses the Scottish Women's national football team's strong performance in qualifiers, currently undefeated with five wins. The team is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their top position in the group. Player Claire Evans expresses her desire to avoid the heartbreak of missing out on major competitions, having experienced play-off losses in the past. The team aims to reach the finals, with Evans noting the emotional significance of this achievement.

Scotland is in a strong position to qualify for next summer's finals in the Netherlands without a play-off, thanks to their undefeated record and the fact that the best six of the eight group runners-up qualify automatically. Iceland, currently ranked one place above Scotland, is also performing well, with four wins from four games.

Evans highlights the benefits of having players from the national team playing in top leagues abroad, such as Bayern Munich, which contributes to the overall improvement and competitiveness of the team. She also shares her experience playing in Germany, where the women's football league is considered one of the best in the world, and how training with top-level players has made her a better player. The

The passage discusses the use of third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud, and the implementation of two-step verification as a safety measure to prevent this. Apple has made two-factor authentication an opt-in feature, but one expert suggests it should be the default. The process involves entering a four-digit code after typing in a username and password, either via text or the Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases is denied. A recovery key can be used to regain access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple had previously not required two-step verification for accessing iCloud backups, but this has changed. The owner of the forensic software believed to have been used in the hacks acknowledges that Apple's changes guard against his technique but expresses concerns about the recovery key's security and usability. Another security expert recommends making two-factor authentication the default for Apple and other companies. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage provides a comparison of the campaign expenditures and spending per vote for the main political parties in the UK during the 2014 European election campaign. UKIP spent the most, £2,956,737, and had the highest spending per vote at 68 p. Labour came in second with a spending of £1,027,339 and a spending per vote of 26 p. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815, with a spending per vote of 79 p, while the Liberal Democrats lost all but one of their MEPs and spent £1,580,575, with a spending per vote of £1.45. The Green Party, coming in fourth, spent £534,249 and had a spending per vote of 43 p. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on their campaigns, with all but Labour spending more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

The passage discusses two football transfers: 

1. Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, has ended his contract with Barrow by mutual agreement to join their National League rivals. He has experience playing for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. He may play against his former club on February 18th.

2. Striker Keating, 21, is set to join Gulls after being recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. His previous teams include Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is contingent upon international clearance. Kevin Nicholson, Gulls' boss, sees Keating as young, hungry, and raw but believes he can contribute to the team.

The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." The horse had no significant underlying health issues and had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. The horse had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

The passage recounts the emotional farewell speeches of veteran MSPs Alex Salmond and Duncan McNeil, who are among those standing down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's unity and the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but expressed dissatisfaction with its fulfillment of unionist politicians' pledges during the referendum campaign. Salmond also shared a lighthearted moment, comparing his speech to the Cheltenham Champion Chase. He concluded by praising the parliament and his role in it. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, expressed gratitude to Salmond for his contributions as an MSP and first minister. McNeil, who has served in the parliament since its establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly in terms of the committee system. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also addressed the chamber, joking about her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage announces the casting of Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou in the animated film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Angela Lansbury's role as Mrs. Potts is mentioned, with Kevin Kline cast as Maurice, Belle's father. The film is set to release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, and will be directed by Bill Condon. Filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May.

The passage discusses the upcoming meeting between the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and victims' relatives regarding the Hillsborough disaster, a 1989 stadium tragedy that resulted in the death of 96 football fans. Last year, new inquests concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence files relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS for decision-making. The meeting aims to reveal the CPS's intentions regarding charges for the suspects, with 15 files related to the Operation Resolve investigation and eight to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe. Families will be informed of the decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS. Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expresses the families' determination to seek accountability and their anticipation for the meeting's outcome.

The Chelmsford Prison has faced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with residents and former inmates reporting an influx of mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the efforts of staff to prevent contraband from entering prisons but admits more needs to be done. The Justice Secretary has tasked the Ministry of Justice with finding ways to equip prisons with tools to combat such issues. A resident near the prison has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, and there are claims of drones being used to deliver contraband directly to prison windows. The Ministry of Justice denies this, stating there is no evidence of drones entering the Chelmsford site.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, suffered serious head injuries outside a school in Kempston when Brian Wright, 55, failed to stop for a red light. Wright admitted hitting Blackburn but claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

A concise summary of the passage would be:

- Liz Muir, a middle distance runner, has decided to withdraw from the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies, which conflict with the event's schedule.
- Muir has finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships.
- She expressed disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but prioritized her degree completion.
- Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target for the future.
- She set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m race at the World Athletics Championships in London, where she was part of a tough competition.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, went missing in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search operation involving excavations is underway in a 3-acre woodland area near the River Liffey, expected to take several weeks. Detectives have reviewed CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance, showing Deely talking to a man in black. The man has not been identified and detectives are appealing for him to come forward.

In a tennis match, Argentine player Juan Martin Del Potro secured a victory over Swiss player Stan Wawrinka with a score of 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. Del Potro, ranked 165th, is making a comeback after missing two years due to injury. He will next play either France's Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young. The match was notable for Del Potro's determination and support from fellow players, including Andy Murray. In other tournament news, Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half of the draw as Murray, won his match against Dustin Brown, and Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the next round. The winner would then face Murray or John Millman in the last 16.

The passage discusses the expulsion of Tunisia from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the organization, which were later apologized for. Morocco, previously banned from the 2017 Nations Cup, had its participation overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Both countries' paths to the 2017 Nations Cup are highlighted, with Tunisia facing a contentious penalty in their quarter-final match and Morocco being replaced as hosts of the 2015 Nations Cup. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) was accused of accusing Caf and a referee of corruption, but denied the allegations. Tunisia was eventually allowed to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Both Tunisia and Morocco were placed in their respective groups for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage discusses the history and current struggles of the McLaren Formula 1 racing team. It highlights their past successes, including 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The team's recent decline began in 2013, with issues in chassis design and now with the Honda power-unit. The passage also touches on various scandals and the team's attempts to recover, with team principal Ron Dennis believing they will break Mercedes' dominance in F1.

A concise summary of the passage would be: On 6 October 2014, a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven led to the bar's closure for three months by Limavady Magistrates Court. The court charged Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours due to evidence of alcohol being served late into the night. The judge expressed concern over O'Neill's "appalling record" and lack of power to impose a custodial sentence, fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

A Dutch YouTube star, Bas van Velzen, who was believed to be a competition winner, arrived at Melwood to meet Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. Initially, they thought he was a free-kick specialist. However, it soon became apparent that Van Velzen was not just a regular fan as he demonstrated his goal-scoring skills. The players watched in amazement as Van Velzen showcased his dead-ball skills, even scoring a goal. In return, Balotelli executed a perfect free-kick. Van Velzen, who has gained fame on YouTube for his free-kick exploits, described the experience as amazing and fulfilling every fan's dream to play with their idols.

The passage discusses a study that found women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation can significantly reduce their risk of dying from the disease by having their ovaries removed through an oophorectomy, following the example of Hollywood star Angelina Jolie. The study, which analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 mutations, found that oophorectomy reduced the risk of breast cancer death by over 60% for those with BRCA1 mutations, but not for those with BRCA2 mutations. The researchers suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment for women with early-stage breast cancer who carry BRCA1 mutations, and call for further research, particularly on carriers of the BRCA2 variant.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were fatally struck by an Amtrak train, Train No. 80, the Carolinian, in Durham, North Carolina on Easter Sunday morning. The incident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property as the couple was on the tracks. The train, heading from Charlotte to New York City, had 166 passengers on board, none of whom were injured. A passenger fell ill during the two hours and 45 minutes delay, receiving treatment. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene. The train resumed its journey after the delay. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp, and a man who met them reported their struggles, urging compassion for those in dire circumstances. The train's next destination was Raleigh, 25 miles away from Durham. The journey from Charlotte to New York City typically takes 13 hours and 30 minutes.

The passage recounts the story of Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel who spent 27 years working as an undercover informant for the DEA in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Toro fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and eventually joined the DEA, providing information on his former bosses and associates. He became one of the agency's most important assets, assisting in undercover stings around the world, including the downfall of Carlos Lehder Rivas and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega.

Toro was not paid for his work but was promised US citizenship. However, this promise was not fulfilled, and he is now technically living in the US illegally after retiring due to declining health. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears deportation to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed within four hours. His former DEA handler, Mike McManus, and former colleagues have tried to help him, but Toro remains in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, and is prepared

The passage discusses the efforts of the US regulatory body overseeing internet addresses to crack down on a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge celebrities and companies exorbitant sums, such as $2,499 a year, to have their names removed from the '.sucks' domains. The company has already sold '.sucks' domains for major brands like YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now considering it illegal after receiving complaints from industry groups and companies like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay. ICANN has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to investigate the company's actions. Vox Populi CEO John Berard argues that the company's business is within ICANN rules and the law, but the advisory body considers it a'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory.' If found illegal, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to change the registry's behavior.

A baby boy's body was found 27 years ago in a village pond, and recently, his mother was arrested after a DNA sample led to her identification. The woman, who concealed her pregnancy from family and friends, delivered the stillborn baby and placed him in the pond. The case was initially unsolved, but advances in DNA technology allowed the police to trace the mother. The baby's body was exhumed, and a second post-mortem examination found no evidence of foul play. The woman remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied with his name, Peter, after a support group for parents of stillborn children paid for a new headstone.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving taxi. The incident occurred when Hicks, on his way home from a night out, was mistakenly believed by the driver to be planning to 'do a runner'. The driver, intending to teach Hicks a lesson, continued driving for almost a mile before Hicks jumped out. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care due to his injuries, which include devastating brain damage, epilepsy, and dependence on his mother for care. The High Court judge ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided, with a 50% reduction from the family's requested amount anticipated.

The passage describes a series of storms in Kansas and nearby areas that brought reports of twisters, including one near Goddard and another potentially threatening Potosi, Missouri. The storms caused wind damage, flooding, and hail, with nighttime tornadoes being particularly deadly and dangerous. The weather service predicts more storms in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

The passage discusses an upcoming middleweight clash between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida in New Jersey. Rockhold aims for his fourth consecutive victory since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago, with a title shot in sight. He plans to dominate Machida by cutting him off, controlling the fight, and taking advantage of Machida's weaknesses. Rockhold respects Machida's fighting style but is determined to win the fight. Machida, confident in his ability to upset Rockhold, believes he can earn a title shot if he applies his style and technique. Both fighters acknowledge the other's strengths and respect their fighting styles, but are focused on winning the fight to secure a title shot.

The passage describes a harrowing incident where an Aerostar light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, causing its propellers to ricochet off the ground and bounce the wings up and down from the impact. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off, damaging the propellers. Remarkably, the aircraft managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where it landed safely. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, who has over 50 years of flying experience, was accompanied by his dog, Buddy. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the incident, which is a common occurrence due to human error or mechanical faults.

The passage discusses the situation of Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure, who has faced criticism for his performances this season. Manuel Pellegrini, Manchester City's manager, admitted to being disappointed in Toure but vowed to support the player until the end of the season. Sportsmail revealed that Manchester City is open to offers for Toure, as they aim to refresh their aging squad. Despite the criticism, Pellegrini insists that Toure is an important player and will have his support until the season concludes. Manchester City's poor performance in the Premier League has raised questions about Pellegrini's future, but goalkeeper Joe Hart insists that the players should take responsibility for their performances. The passage also mentions that Manchester City is interested in signing West Ham's left back Aaron Cresswell, and Sam Allardyce warns Cresswell against making the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City.

The passage discusses the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive who was dubbed the "Godfather of Uxbridge" and was set to be extradited to Italy. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in Italy in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra and sentenced to seven years in prison. However, his sentence was dropped due to the expiration of his case last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Rancadore's case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, according to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS). The case highlights the costs and complexities of extradition proceedings, with legal experts expressing frustration over the time and money spent on Rancadore's case.

The passage discusses the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, featuring Mr Mole, Ap McCoy's mount. Mr Mole is installed as one of the 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up, alongside Irish Raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Ap McCoy and Mr Mole will face six rivals in the race, marking Mr Mole's last ride in a Grade One race. McCoy's final day as a professional jockey's book of rides will not be finalized until Friday morning. The announcement of McCoy's retirement came after his victory on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The passage recounts the harrowing story of Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia, who was murdered 40 years ago. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Virginia had been advised against seeing her daughter's body and crime scene photos by her then-husband, Charlie, who passed away in 1989. Despite his advice, Virginia decided to see the crime scene photos last year, a decision she now regrets. She described the photos as horrifying, showing Marcia's mouth black, swollen head, and other parts of her body that looked like her daughter. Virginia expressed a desire for revenge. Jerome Sydney Barrett, now 68, was found guilty of second-degree murder six years ago and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years, with a neighbor initially charged in 1979 but the charges dropped due to lack of evidence. Barrett was eventually arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime.

Summary:

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters at some point to complete his career grand slam, following in the footsteps of only a handful of players including Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. McIlroy's final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was a crucial learning experience for him, and he is now aiming to win all four major titles. Despite only having one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy believes he can win multiple times at the Augusta course and sees it as a place of sanctuary from the pressure and hype. His extraordinary success in 2013 was achieved despite distractions from calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company. McIlroy is looking forward to the Augusta hype and aims to use the golf course as his sanctuary to focus on playing and practicing.

The passage discusses the alarming number of 272 children hospitalized in England over the past year due to foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. The actual number of affected children could be much higher, with research suggesting that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to their mother's drinking. The National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome warns that children with FAS do not improve and the problem is vastly under-diagnosed. The FAS diagnosis usually comes after the child has already suffered significant developmental issues. The passage also mentions other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy and the government's advice for pregnant women to limit their alcohol intake to two units no more than twice a week. However, the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome believes that the guidance should be changed to advise women not to drink alcohol at all during pregnancy.

A robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. He was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him to the floor, and his wife, Sam, hit him with a baseball bat. McKerry, a former juvenile offender with numerous arrests and convictions, was known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes.

The passage describes the legal situation of four Royal Navy sailors who have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks. They must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. The accused are Joshua Finbow, 23, a submarine engineer from Hampshire; Simon Radford, 31, from Gosport, Hampshire; Craig Stoner, 24, from Stonehouse, Gloucestershire; and Darren Smalley, 35, also from Gosport, Hampshire. They were granted bail with unusual conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the nearby Stadacona naval base in Halifax. Bail is set at over £2,000 each. They will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay during the trial. The alleged sexual assault occurred on April 10, after the sailors had returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The four men are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still at an early stage, and additional charges could result from forensic tests.

The passage is about a mother, Valerie Jackson, whose son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease that makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and covered in dry, scaly skin. Due to the condition, RJ's mother has to regularly cover him in creams to prevent his skin from drying out. However, RJ's condition has led to misunderstandings and mistreatment from others. A stranger once reported Valerie to the police for child abuse, believing RJ was being scalded. Valerie has also faced taunts from other mothers and cruel comments from people in the street. Despite the challenges, Valerie remains committed to educating others about Netherton's syndrome and hopes that as her son grows, his condition will be better understood by society.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertising campaign featuring a bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield on the London Underground. The adverts were met with backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a change.org petition calling for their removal which attracted over 50,000 signatures. The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints about the adverts, and they promoted an unhealthy body image. TfL confirmed that the posters were being removed due to the end of their advertising period. Protein World acknowledged the public's reaction and stated they would consider it in the future. The posters were defaced by some, and a protest against Protein World was organized. The company defended their campaign, stating it aimed to make the nation healthier and encourage fitness. Protein World faced threats and a bomb threat, but the company's head insisted the campaign was not meant to offend and was targeted at health-conscious individuals looking to get fit. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints. Sales of protein powder in the UK have been increasing due to the growing fitness culture.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding rail firms planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite the main party leaders' pledges to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. Cameron has promised to freeze fares in real terms for the whole of the next parliament, and Labour has pledged to cap price hikes. The planned fare increases have angered Cameron's constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. Train companies have three windows every year to increase unregulated fares, which make up around half of their total revenue. Unregulated fares can include off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets.
