First Great Western insists the reason for the fare increase is to bring the North Cotswolds route in line with its other services.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was left blind in one eye after thugs threw a brick through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester, when he confronted them about throwing stones at his property. The incident occurred while Young and his new wife, Elaine, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts. Young suffered a serious injury to his left eye and an open wound to his forehead, but doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The police have launched an investigation, but there appears to be no motive and it may be a case of yobs'messing around'.

Derby Shire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully recovering from leg injuries sustained in a road accident. He missed the entire 2014 campaign due to injuries and underwent an ankle operation. Poynton made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, and expressed hope that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well this summer.

A five-year-old boy named Harley, who was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of cancer called neuroblastoma, has been declared cancer-free after a year-long battle. The disease affected his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. Harley found comfort in wearing a ninja turtle mask during his radiotherapy treatment, which was decorated by himself. His story gained international attention, and he received a box of Ninja Turtle presents from the children's TV channel Nickelodeon. Harley's parents were given the incredible news that he is free of cancer, and he will undergo regular check-ups to ensure his continued health. Harley has also become the face of Cancer Research UK's kids and teens campaign, raising funds for research into child cancers.

The passage discusses Tim Sherwood's advice to Jack Grealish regarding his international future. Sherwood, impressed by Grealish's performance in Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, urges the 19-year-old to focus on his club career rather than deciding on his international allegiance. Grealish is currently at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England, and Sherwood wants him to continue proving himself in the Villa first team. Sherwood compares Grealish's situation to that of Nabil Bentaleb, advising Grealish to make the decision based on his heart. Grealish is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season, and his father, Kevin, agrees that club football should be his priority.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for those who travel by private jet, revealing insights into some of the most unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the rich and famous. It highlights the luxury of owning a private jet and the need to continually pay for landing charges, which can reach thousands of dollars each time. The text also mentions the growing trend of private jet travel, with millions of private flights recorded in the US and Europe in 2013. It provides examples of expensive airports for landing fees, including Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, which charges £4,559 (or $6,850) for landing a 767-400 jet. The passage also mentions the busiest weekends for private jets, which occur during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix.

The passage recounts a humorous incident where Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dog, Cooper the Labrador, and Daisy, a smaller female pup, to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. Despite Cooper's slow-food movement intentions, he quickly devours the entire cone in one bite, while Daisy takes a few more ladylike licks. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, ensures Daisy gets her fill first to avoid any food disputes. The video of this event has garnered over seven million views and has been met with mixed reactions, with some finding it cute and hilarious, while others criticize Gallegos for feeding her pups McDonald's ice cream. Gallegos defends her actions, mentioning that Cooper is an athlete in excellent health, and that her previous dog, Sammy, also enjoyed an ice cream treat once a week until he passed away at 19 years old. The two dogs are shown to have a penchant for fast food, as another video shows them enjoying a non-coffee "pup-uccino" at Starbucks, with Cooper again consuming the entire cup in one go.

The passage discusses the appointment of Gary Locke as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock. Locke, who initially took over as interim manager after Allan Johnston's departure in February, has now been given the role permanently. He signed a three-year deal and has led the team with success, losing only once in seven games. The announcement was made at a press conference, where he shook hands with Kilmarnock's chairman, Jim Mann.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accuses a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to help with his illness. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied to Logan's head and neck by his mother to keep him calm and focused. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary warned they would remove Logan from class because the oils smelled and distracted other children. Despite the threat of punishment, Mrs. Kemp plans to fight the decision and insists the use of the oils has a positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District stated it would not suspend Logan, considering it a health issue. The family uses Doterra oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which the company describes as being "beautifully and powerfully fragrant."

The passage describes a devastating fire that occurred at a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, the Hamptons, resulting in the destruction of 90 condos and the eventual collapse of the building. The cause of the fire remains unknown, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews and cranes, they were unable to enter the condos to fight the flames. The building manager, Rob Taber, lost everything in the fire. The investigation into the cause suggests it may have started near a car parked near the complex. The affected building, the Sandpiper Complex, was used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The passage describes the Queen's love for horses and her continued equestrian activities despite a niggling knee injury that has reduced the amount of time she spends in the saddle. She is known for her preference to ride in a silk headscarf rather than a helmet, citing her need to have her hair done as the reason. The Queen has a long history with horses, having first found herself in the saddle at the age of four. She has owned various horses and ponies, including a black fell pony named Carltonlima Emma, and has a stud specializing in Highland ponies at Balmoral. The Queen's fell ponies are highly prized, having roamed the moors of Cumbria since the Neolithic period and being used by various ancient tribes and invaders. The fell pony's gentle nature and pretty looks made it popular as a riding horse in the 1950s, and the Queen continues to breed several breeds of horse and pony, including fell ponies, at her Hampton Court stud.

A tragic incident occurred in Brisbane when a dispute between two neighbors, one making loud noise, escalated into violence resulting in the death of Leon Yeaman, 55. Phillip Pama, 28, allegedly killed Yeaman with a single punch during the altercation. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was granted conditional bail and faced charges of manslaughter. Yeaman was known for his loud behavior and Pama was attempting to sleep at the time of the disturbance. Pama's defense lawyer stated that his client was pushed and hit out blindly during the confrontation. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was ordered to surrender his passport, abide by a curfew, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder a 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit, and detailed her desire for the victim to slowly bleed to death. A sting operation by the police recorded this meeting, leading to Simonova's arrest and a potential 15-year prison sentence for attempted murder.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, has a strong faith in God and prays every day, but only discusses personal matters and never football, with God or his wife. He is an ambassador for the World Food Programme against hunger and tries to separate his professional life from his family. Mourinho admits to an intensely arrogant persona on the sideline but believes he is a good person, a good family man, and a good friend. He has been fined by football authorities for claiming there was a campaign against Chelsea.

The passage recounts an episode of "The Price is Right" on April 1, where TV legend Bob Barker made a surprise return after eight years. At 91, Barker hosted the show, including the "Lucky Seven" game, before handing over the hosting duties to Drew Carey. Barker, who previously hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, appeared to be in good form and did not miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested for allegedly attempting to break into a house in Washington D.C. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who was working with the foreign missions branch of the Secret Service, which is attached to the State Department, had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave. His arrest took place on the 3200 block of D Street SE, not long after midnight on Friday. Baldwin's court arraignment was scheduled for Friday afternoon. This incident comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to allegations of misconduct, which is being investigated by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion in the city's safari park. He got out of his car, crept up to within 10 feet of the lion, and took a few frames before the lion's attention was drawn to the camera's shutter sound, forcing him to retreat rapidly. Saeed described the encounter as a "pretty close" one, but now regrets his decision to take such a risk.

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious and later died on a Brooklyn street on March 22nd. The New York City Police have released an image of a distinctive tattoo, a faded heart with the name "Monique" on her leg, in an attempt to identify her. The tattoo is believed to be a heart with a rose, containing the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon. The cause of her death is yet to be determined by a medical examiner's report. The public is urged to contact the NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS if they have any information regarding the unidentified woman.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned home from the UK in 2009 without the funds to purchase a full-sized property. They decided to build a home on the back of an old 1986 Hino flatbed truck, transforming it into a solar-powered, two-bedroom wood and steel home. The project took them a year and a half to complete and cost them around $25,000. The couple now lives in Nelson, New Zealand, in their eco-friendly home, which is nearly self-sufficient, powered by solar panels and utilizing water from a nearby spring.

The passage discusses a study conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, which found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class outperformed those who did not, in early literacy tests. The best outcomes were observed when children shared devices, with shared iPad students scoring around 30 points higher than those who used the device on their own and non-ipad users. The study involved 352 students at a midwestern suburban school district and suggests that collaborative learning around technology made the difference, not just the collaboration in and of itself. Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage describes a two-legged piglet that has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on just its front trotters. Born without back legs, the piglet has mastered balance and is seen taking unsteady steps while foraging for food. The heartwarming video of the piglet's attempts to walk has captured the hearts of thousands. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan province, Southwestern China, and has been visited by villagers eager to see the curious animal. This is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to gain attention in China, as a rabbit at the Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25, spun out while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released from the infield care center. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the race. Dracone did not finish the race, finishing in 23rd place.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by slamming her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the act due to jealousy over other men looking at her. The incident was captured on security camera. Cicera Alves de Sena was a member of a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas. After the crime, Severiano stole a neighbor's car, which he crashed during his escape. He was found with four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest. Severiano now faces life in jail.

The passage is a candid interview with Sarah Wilson, the journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," who shares her personal struggle with mental illness, particularly anxiety, which at one point led her to believe that her life wasn't worth living. Wilson, now 41, discusses how her anxiety reached a peak due to a combination of stress, her thyroid disease, and distant family relationships, making her feel increasingly isolated and alone. She highlights the link between depression and anxiety and believes that acknowledging this connection is crucial to better address the growing issue of stress and anxiety affecting Australian women. Wilson emphasizes the importance of seeking help and provides contact details for Beyondblue (1300 224 636) and Lifeline (13 11 14) for those in need.

A pregnant woman from Oregon, Elena Curtin, was charged with second-degree assault for beating her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom. Curtin was seven months pregnant at the time of the incident in November 2014. She was set to go to trial, but prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." The ex-girlfriend had been jealous and bitter about Curtin's relationship with her boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child. The boyfriend struggled with heroin in the past and they have a five-year-old child together. Curtin's defense attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend had made Curtin's life miserable and was an intruder who refused to leave Curtin's home. If Curtin had been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes a humorous incident where Gemma, a pit bull dog, is filmed being fed treats at her home in California. Her owner tries to trick her by throwing a broccoli spear among the treats. Gemma immediately reacts with disgust, tries to eat the vegetable, and then spits it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma lives with two children and hopes they learn to love their greens, while she enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family when not eating.

A link on HSBC's official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page after the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards page was shut down and its registration expired. The URL transferred visitors to the porn site instead. HSBC apologized and removed the hyperlink from its main website. The bank assured that its website and internet banking service remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 to get himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, rescued from a fire in their Clinton home. The siblings were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after the fire started on the first floor. Marcus stayed calm during the 11-minute call, providing directions to firefighters and reassuring his sister. The family's other members were also inside the home and were either rescued by themselves or taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

The passage describes a phenomenon of blue fluorescent algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, lighting up Australia's east coast, particularly Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow illuminating a popular beach and described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene." This display, which also occurred at Manly Beach in Sydney in August 2014, is caused by the single-celled phytoplankton and is generally a natural occurrence, happening in 90% of cases. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explains that the algae blossoms in the spring and autumn and emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism against its prey, another type of algae called diatoms.

The passage discusses the potential of new genetic tests, specifically the Endopredict test, to determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the risk of recurrence. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, allowing women to be informed within days of their risk level. For some women, the test accurately predicts a risk as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than the odds for those undergoing chemotherapy. Currently, most women diagnosed with breast cancer receive chemotherapy following tumor removal to prevent recurrence, despite its side effects like hair loss, nausea, sickness, weight gain or loss, and extreme fatigue. The Endopredict test allows patients to make an informed decision about whether to undergo chemotherapy. While most tests are currently available privately at a cost of about £2,500, breast specialists hope they may soon be available on the NHS, with potential savings from not giving chemotherapy to those with a low risk score.

The passage discusses the issue of pregnant women being airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to strict military rules that ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones. Over the last nine years, more than 25 women have been evacuated from ships, including five from the HMS Ocean and at least one from the HMS Illustrious (nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before decommissioning). The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea, suggesting that the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. The data also mentions the case of Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was evacuated after claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member, leading to a military investigation and her replacement. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone was found with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The discovery is raising concerns about terrorism attempts in the future, particularly at the Olympics and G7 summit, using drones. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence and government buildings.

A 84-year-old woman suffering from Alzheimer's in China is taken to work by her son, Lu Xincai, every day on the back of his motorbike. Lu, a security guard from Zhejiang province, is concerned that his mother may get lost if left alone due to her condition. He ties a sash around both of their waists to prevent her from falling off the bike. Lu's decision to bring his mother to work was made because his wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. At work, his mother has her own room, and Lu checks on her regularly to ensure she hasn't wandered off. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother now, as she devoted her life to raising him and his siblings.

The passage discusses a major study on alcohol use that found heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. The study, conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, found that heavy drinking was defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking was defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increases in heavy drinking and binge drinking were driven largely by women's drinking habits, with social norms changing. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, and it found that in 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. The passage also mentions that 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, with the cost of excessive drinking estimated at more than $220 billion per year. Public health experts offer cultural and economic explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including changed

The passage discusses the increasing trend of caesarean sections (C-sections) performed on women, with UN officials warning that doctors are performing them too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The UN officials emphasize that the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections, complications, disability, or even death. The rate of C-sections in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with just over a quarter of women now having a C-section. The World Health Organisation (WHO) states that the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and costs involved. The WHO warns that C-sections are often performed without medical need, putting women and their babies at risk of short- and long-term health problems. The cost of a planned C-section is higher than a natural birth, with the NHS spending an average of £2,369 compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO's statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which offer the procedure to women even without medical justification. The WHO urges doctors to be more cautious and consider the risks

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins, from West Wareham, was arrested for breaking into a $800,000 home on Martha's Vineyard and living there for a week. She sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale and was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, found her in the living room and called the police, who discovered a broken window. Filkins fled in a truck and was later arrested when she tried to get back into the home. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and are offering assistance to those who bought the items in seeking restitution.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was found and reunited with its owner after being handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. The police, realizing the phone was unlocked, used it to post selfies and humorous messages on Bella's Facebook page to track her down. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and had it handed in to the police station. The police posted updates on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a holding "cell" and reassuring her that the phone was in safe hands. Bella was eventually recognized from her Facebook page and did not have to give her name to reclaim her phone. The police's unusual approach was well-received, with Bella's friends calling the officers "legends" and Bella herself thanking the police for their good sense of humor. Bella has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The baby's mother watched in horror as it was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface before eventually dying from its injuries. The mother had previously tried to protect her baby from other young hippos, possibly believing it safer to stay out of the fight herself. The cause of the fatal attack on the baby remains uncertain.

The passage describes a three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, which is being sold for £575,000, significantly below the market price of similar properties in the area. The catch is that the apartment has only three years left on its lease. The cost of the lease extension could potentially make the property worth upwards of £6 million. The apartment is located in Egerton Place, an exclusive area known for its high-end properties. The passage also mentions that the next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million, with a 28-year lease. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson, and the current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust. The lease extension would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease.

A computer outage at Starbucks affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The issue began in the early evening on the east coast and in the late afternoon on the west coast. The outage was resolved, and stores were expected to open for business as usual the following day. Starbucks did not explain the cause of the outage but later stated it was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Some locations closed early to avoid giving away free products, while others continued to serve customers. The incident occurred the day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

The passage discusses the training of terrorists in rural areas of West Wales, particularly in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, where they are radicalizing Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit explains that these individuals participate in seemingly normal community activities with an ulterior motive. The passage also mentions incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, with the area's rugged terrain being used by the British military for training. The passage highlights several instances of terrorism-related activities in Wales, including the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby by Michael Adebowale, who studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder. Detective Constable Jones emphasizes the importance of community intelligence in identifying potential threats.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, which was thought to be extinct, has been found washed up on a West Australian beach. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The discovery was made after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn affected the area. The Omura's whale was identified through DNA profiling. This find is significant for scientists as it provides them with the opportunity to learn more about the species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003. The knowledge gained will help improve field identification guides and better understand the whale's regional distribution. The species is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Omura's whales have a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possibly for public display in museums.

The passage discusses the idea that hormones play a significant role in presidential candidates' decisions, particularly focusing on the concerns of a female businesswoman in Texas who believes Hillary Clinton should not be president due to her hormones potentially making her irrational. The author also mentions George W. Bush and the Iraq war, suggesting that testosterone might have played a role in his decision-making. The passage then contrasts this with studies showing that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. It goes on to discuss the bias against women in the workplace and how it affects female candidates' chances of being elected president. The author argues that the goal should be to eradicate gender stereotypes and promote equality, which benefits everyone, including the economy and families.

Summary: Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of antiques worth £100,000 at an auction to downsize his home. The collection includes over 200 items, a pair of early Victorian furniture, a painting of Hardy holding a longbow, a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes 238 lots, including books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and "Winston Churchill" TV dramas, is a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow.

A Florida man, Michael Scott Shemansky, is wanted by police as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. An initial investigation determined foul play. Michael is already on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness. His wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings may have led to the murder. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Michael is on the run, without medication, and anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact the police.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event for the first time in the USA. Eugene had previously failed to host the 2019 event, which went to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF was persuaded by Eugene's recent presentation, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and a supportive public. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic decision and the opportunity to access a key market and promote global development of athletics. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

A 25-year-old aspiring model, Leonie Granger, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for her role in the death of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger lured Hassan into his home with the intention of stealing his winnings, but her accomplices, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, kicked him to death during the robbery. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

The passage discusses the inconsistent performance of Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, particularly during the second half of the season. It highlights his decline in form from the player who was on track to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists, to being one of the worst players on the pitch in recent matches. Fabregas' international debut since October was met with criticism, receiving a score of just four out of ten from a Spanish newspaper. The passage also touches on Fabregas' happiness in London and his role as a key player in Chelsea's title charge, but questions remain about his durability. His form has dropped off from the brilliant start to the season, and it is suggested that his long and intense campaign in England is taking its toll. Fabregas' former club, Barcelona, had previously commented on his reputation for a late-season slump, which seems to have affected his performance this season. Despite his struggles, Fabregas' potential resurgence could be crucial for Chelsea's pursuit of the Premier League title.

The passage discusses West Ham's interest in Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United. Beckford impressed West Ham's academy coaches after a two-week trial period and has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. He is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean and has been linked with several European clubs. West Ham is close to signing him, and to fill the 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium during the 2016-17 season, the club is offering season tickets at the cheapest pricing in the Barclays Premier League, starting at £289.

A man named Mike Lane, who is 40 years old and a leader of a group called the Tedworth Hunt, was badly hurt by some people wearing masks and carrying long, heavy sticks. The police had some clues about who did it, like a video and a list of names, but they decided not to look any further because they didn't have enough proof. Mike and his family are very upset and feel like the police didn't try hard enough to find the people who hurt him.

The passage is about Adam Gadahn, a former American citizen who became known as the American mouthpiece of al Qaeda. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, joining al Qaeda and adopting the name Abu Suhayb. He rose to prominence within al Qaeda as its chief official English-language propagandist, producing numerous videos threatening attacks on the United States and advocating for the overthrow of the U.S. and Pakistani governments. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda and was listed as one of the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." He was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January 2010.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a viral sensation for his exceptional basketball skills. Since the age of two and a half, Mai has been practicing basketball, and in a recent video, he demonstrates impressive abilities such as scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs at the same time. His focused eyes and seamless handling of the balls have won him a large following in basketball-loving China. Mai's talents have even left netizens questioning if the video is real or if it's a special effects trick, and some are even feeling embarrassed about their own basketball skills in comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, which advocated for the legalisation of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, was formed in 1974. The group, which also had an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), lobbied for the age of sexual consent to be lowered to ten, and wanted to legalise incest. Tom O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO), calling it "biased and unfair," and wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry.

The passage describes an unusual fashion show held at the Bondi Icebergs Club pool during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The pool was drained to create a unique catwalk for the "Ten Pieces" presentation, a capsule collection of unisex clothing designed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. The collection, featuring monochrome designs, consists of ten pieces that can be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day to night wear. The show was attended by guests who enjoyed snacks and drinks, and passers-by stopped to watch the fashion spectacle from the road above the pool.

The passage describes a day off for Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter Lamysa, as they visited a safari park in Northern California. Amir Khan interacted with various animals, including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. The family enjoyed a day of adventure together. Meanwhile, Amir Khan addressed speculation about his next opponent by announcing a fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30. He had previously faced pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June and was also linked with fights against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman. However, Khan clarified that he was already deep in negotiations for another opponent.

A 16-year-old Palestinian, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, had his name added to an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. However, his family and Almagor, an organization supporting victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, considering his death a rogue attack and not a terror victim. Almagor demanded his name's removal from the memorial, threatening to remove their own family members' names if his wasn't. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, has agreed to remove his name following his father's complaints.

The passage describes a California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, who filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden in an attempt to use its belly as a pillow for rest. The cat initially allows the child to sit on it before getting up and moving to another spot, leading the child to follow and repeat the action. Eventually, the cat becomes tired of this and goes indoors. In a later video, the duo reconciles, with the child giving the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with one trial witness, Robert Kushner, losing his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is among more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying against allegations of police wrongdoing. He claimed that some undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner's 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence, but he was arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. The school officials were unaware of Kushner's past when he was hired to coach basketball in 2010.

A chemical plant in China's Fujian province, which produces carcinogenic paraxylene (PX) used in polyester production, experienced an explosion and fire due to an oil leak at an oil storage facility. Six people were injured, five from broken glass, and have been treated. Over 600 firefighters extinguished the blaze, now under control. The plant, originally planned for Xiamen, was relocated to Zhangzhou due to protests and pollution concerns in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland U21 international, has a unique superstition of wearing his socks low due to using children's shinpads. Despite Premier League referees advising him to pull up his socks, Grealish plans to maintain this style, especially after making his first Premier League start on a challenging night. He expressed satisfaction in getting his first start out of the way, noting it was a tough game in a relegation fight but hoping to earn more starts before the season ends.

The passage discusses the critical condition of Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, who has suffered global and irreversible brain damage. At 22 years old, she remains unresponsive and has been out of a medically induced coma. Cissy Houston, her grandmother, shared her concerns about Bobbi Kristina's condition, stating that she may live in this state for a lifetime and that they are now relying on God for a miracle. Despite Bobby Brown reporting an improvement in his daughter's condition, the neurological state has not changed significantly for the past three months. Bobbi Kristina has a tracheostomy and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. Her quality of life and the course of her rehabilitation remain uncertain.

In a Fed Cup tennis match, Russia secured a 2-0 lead with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova narrowly defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki after saving a match point in the second set, and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova attributed her difficulty to Lisicki's powerful game, while Lisicki acknowledged her own unforced errors as crucial factors in her loss. Despite both players facing service issues, Russia now requires one win from Sunday's matches to advance to the final and potentially win their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

The passage describes the ongoing impact of severe weather in New South Wales, with residents being warned of potential more floods and damage due to another storm predicted to hit later in the week. The same weather system responsible for last week's wild weather is expected to hit the region again, potentially bringing heavy rain from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hinder their cleanup efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs left to complete from the 24,196 requests they received last week. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which suffered significant flooding and high winds during the previous storm. Meteorologists predict that a trough of low pressure will hit the far northern parts of the state, with heaviest rain. The SES advises residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation. The passage also includes a breakdown of weather forecasts for various cities in New South Wales, with some areas expected to have showers later in the week.

A concise summary of the passage would be: Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model and former wife of famous paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, has denied claims that she attempted suicide and was found by her mother in Milan. Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, posted photos of her bruises on Instagram, explaining that she was treated in the hospital due to a fall caused by low blood pressure, not a suicide attempt. Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, confirmed that she was indeed treated for a fall, but suggested that she is a victim of people trying to harm her reputation. Italian media had previously reported that Moric had tried to take her own life in 2009. Moric reassured her fans that she is recovering and not intending to end her life.

The passage discusses public opinion on the potential name choices for the second child of Prince William and Kate Middleton, with a focus on a recent YouGov survey for the Sunday Times. The most favored name for a girl is Diana, in honor of Prince William's mother, the late Princess of Wales. Alice and Charlotte were the next most preferred names, receiving 9% of the vote each. For a boy, the most favored name is James, with 13% of people supporting it, followed by Alexander. The majority of the public (25%) wished for a female baby, with only 3% hoping for a boy. The poll also revealed support for Prince William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64 others near a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan, on Thursday. The attack occurred as the protesters were en route to a rally against the provincial governor. The Afghan lawmaker participating in the protests was among the wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has had a successful seven years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Alves' agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that the player has refused a three-year contract extension, which required him to play in 60% of matches. The negotiations are now over, and Alves will depart from the Nou Camp this summer.

The passage is about Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old Argentinian footballer who recently joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, expressing his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that both players, known for their exceptional skills and popularity in their respective countries, would be a perfect fit for Boca Juniors and would be well-received by the fans at the La Bombonera pitch.

The passage recounts the story of 18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, who experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the ordeal, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut on his nose. The fall has since gone viral online, watched by hundreds of thousands of people. Despite the incident, Ferguson remains undeterred and is determined to get back in the saddle. He described the fall as a "blur" and mentioned that he was lucky to escape with only a minor injury. Ferguson joked about possibly pursuing a gymnastics career after retiring from racing due to the nature of his fall.

The passage discusses James Haskell's Instagram post where he dressed as Robert Downey Jr.'s character, Iron Man, in celebration of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie release. The post gained attention as Haskell is the London Wasps captain and has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand. The passage also mentions Haskell's return to the Wasps club in 2012, where he surpassed the 100 appearances mark and has earned 57 caps for the England squad.

The passage discusses the resurgence of the wide-leg trouser trend in the spring/summer 2015 fashion season. It highlights the versatility of wide-leg trousers in different fabrics, lengths, and styles, such as denim, cropped, printed, and striped. The trend is praised for its effortless appeal and serves as an alternative to the skinny jean. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp, Emma Willis, and Poppy Delevingne have been seen wearing wide-leg trousers. The key to wearing wide-leg trousers successfully is to pair them with high heels and a simple top to maintain proportion and elongate the leg. The passage also mentions various brands that have incorporated the wide-leg trouser into their collections, such as Gucci, Topshop, Celine, and Stella McCartney. The trend is versatile and suitable for both day and evening wear.

The University of Michigan decided to go ahead with the screening of the film "American Sniper" despite a petition signed by over 200 students who asked the school not to show the movie as part of UMix, a series of social events for students. The petition was based on concerns that the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people, given the large Arab-American population in the Detroit metropolitan area. However, there was a backlash to the decision to cancel the movie, leading to a counter-petition requesting reconsideration. Vice President for Student Life, E. Royster Harper, announced that the initial decision to cancel the movie was a mistake and that the film will be screened, consistent with the university's high value on freedom of expression. UMix will also offer a family-friendly screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." The announcement was met with praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

The passage describes an incident where two French tourists attempted to set a quokka, an Australian animal the size of a domestic cat, alight on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia. The quokka was found on Rottnest and Bald islands near Perth and Albany. The tourists, aged 18 and 24, living in Cockburn Central, ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with the quokka on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. The men were questioned by detectives, who also seized video evidence of the act. Both were charged with animal cruelty, and the case will be heard in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

A 102-year-old dancer, Alice Barker, who was part of chorus lines in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and the Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen any of the motion pictures made of her or her photographs and memorabilia, which were lost over the years. With help from filmmakers and Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com, Alice was shown a video of "soundies" - early music videos - and was delighted to see herself dancing for the first time.

The passage discusses the decline of the traditional Sunday car washing routine in Britain. The study by vehicle leasing firm OSV reveals that 31% of men and 75% of women have never washed their own car. Only 12% of men who do wash their cars do it regularly, and only 5% of those surveyed have ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. Factors contributing to the decline include the rise of hand car washes, the increase in live football on TV, and the larger size of modern cars. However, car washing is more common during holidays, with the Easter break seeing an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by their owners. The frequency of car washing by owners varies by location and car brand.

The passage discusses the impact of Steven Gerrard on Martin Skrtel since his arrival at Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel praises Gerrard for helping him settle at the club and considers him one of the best players in the world. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, looking to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal. If successful, he will play his final game at Anfield on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing Gerrard and has potential replacements for the iconic No. 8.

In a concise summary, Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, achieved a hole in one on the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus' first hole in one on the Augusta turf. The event saw five hole-in-ones, equaling the record from 2002. Camilo Villegas, the Colombian golfer, managed two hole-in-ones but lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Jack Nicklaus, a legendary golfer, has won six green jackets, making him one of the five men to complete the career grand slam.

The passage describes a series of storms in Kansas and nearby areas that brought reports of twisters, posing potential risks to communities. Tornadoes were spotted near Goddard and in Southwestern Kansas. Storms also affected the small town of Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and hail. The CNN severe weather expert, Chad Myers, mentioned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. The National Weather Service predicts more storms in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

A 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a taser. The judge allowed Bates to go on vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from the victim's family. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The family's lawyer claims Bates was not qualified for the force and received preferential treatment due to donations and a personal connection to the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations and released Bates' training documents, which his lawyers claim prove his proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

The passage discusses Conor McGregor's upcoming featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. It also mentions McGregor's unveiling of a new tattoo, a tiger's face, on his stomach, and his previous tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. The text highlights McGregor's belief that Aldo lacks the same motivation as him for the fight. It also recounts an incident where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during their promotional tour in Dublin, which adds to the rivalry between the two fighters.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's public display of drinking a beer, known as "skolling," at an Australian Rules function. Critics argue that his actions glorify binge drinking and promote the stereotype that being a man is associated with heavy drinking. Professor Julie Robert from the University of Technology Sydney criticizes the Prime Minister for showcasing his masculinity by drinking a beer quickly, suggesting that it sets up a culture that prioritizes quantity and speed over socializing. The incident sparked debate over whether Abbott's actions and the media's reaction to them contribute to irresponsible drinking practices and perpetuate the stereotype that being a true blue Australian involves drinking heavily. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that there is nothing wrong with his behavior.

The passage discusses the significant increase in HIV cases in Indiana's Scott County, which has occurred more than two weeks into a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. There are now 120 confirmed HIV cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 last week. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The growing number of cases could put pressure on Pence to extend the 30-day needle exchange program. The outbreak has occurred among intravenous drug users, primarily involving the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana. Since the program's approval, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants. The future of the Scott County program and the fate of legislation allowing needle exchange programs in other counties are uncertain. Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, and there is concern that needle exchanges could promote drug use instead of preventing it. The House has approved legislation that would allow 23 Indiana counties with the highest rate-per-population of hepatitis C to establish their own needle-exchange programs, but the Senate is unsure whether to support

In this passage, a football fan named Timothy tests his girlfriend Saskia's knowledge about his favorite team, Arsenal, by making her take a quiz. The quiz was similar to a school exam with multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and an 'in your own words' section. Saskia scored an impressive 87%, which impressed her boyfriend and prevented him from dumping her. She shared the experience on Twitter, and her performance impressed fellow football fans who called her "proper gf material." Some, however, thought Timothy took things too far.

A 66-year-old informant, Carlos Toro, who spent 27 years working for the DEA as an undercover operative in exchange for US citizenship, is facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, helped the DEA carry out undercover stings around the world, including assisting in the downfall of Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Despite not being paid for his work, he was promised US citizenship, which has not been granted. The DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears for his life if deported to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed within four hours.

A 14-year-old girl in India was allegedly gang-raped by five men and set herself on fire in response to the attack. She is currently in a critical condition with 70% burns in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The accused men have been arrested. The issue of sexual assault in India has become a significant concern, leading to protests and calls for more protection for women. The documentary "India's Daughter," which documented the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student in Delhi, was banned by officials due to the heightened sensitivity surrounding the issue.

The passage discusses Manchester United Manager Louis van Gaal's preparation for the derby match against Manchester City at Old Trafford. Van Gaal expresses his dream of beating City in the match but will have to do so without the services of Robin van Persie, who was ruled out due to ankle trouble despite claiming fitness. Van Gaal also mentioned the importance of the match for United's position in the table, potentially securing third place and avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. The manager acknowledged City's challenge and played down the idea of revenge, having lost the away fixture earlier in the season. Van Gaal also ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw, stating both Van Persie and Shaw are not yet fit enough to play. The passage also highlights the training sessions, player interactions, and the strong support from United's fans.

The passage describes a protest by Arsenal and Liverpool fans against the high ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium during their Premier League clash. Fans from both clubs left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes, displaying banners against the rising costs of modern football. The protest was sparked by the £5.14 billion TV rights deal of the Premier League and the £64 starting price for tickets at the sold-out stadium. The fans hope that showing empty seats will raise awareness of the financial struggles they face to attend matches. Organizers of the event, including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, called ticket prices "extortionate" and criticized the prioritization of money over the love of the game and the fans themselves. The protest aims to demand tangible reductions in ticket prices to match the earnings of working-class individuals, fearing that otherwise, a generation or more of fans may be lost.

A newborn baby girl with a life-threatening liver condition, biliary atresia, was saved after receiving a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister. The baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed shortly after birth and underwent an operation to unblock her bile ducts. When it was determined that she needed a liver transplant, neither her mother nor father was a suitable match. Her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered to donate part of her liver, which saved her niece's life. Star's parents were initially unaware of the severity of the condition, and her twin sister was an ideal donor. After the transplant in November, Star has made a good recovery and continues to receive medical care.

The passage describes a football challenge event organized by Audi, featuring Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian. The event consisted of various challenges, including shooting balls into the boot of a car from close range, hitting balls into convertible Audis from long range, and playing a makeshift tennis game over an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian secured victory in the final challenge. The players also experienced misfortune, with Willian accidentally damaging one of the Audi cars.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, 54, from New Hampshire, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger claimed during his sentencing that he was not suicidal on the day of the crash. The couple, Amanda Murphy, 24, and Jason Timmons, 29, were killed instantly, and Amanda was eight months pregnant. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. His attorneys claimed he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis.

A woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, who was convicted of killing her five-year-old son by poisoning him with salt, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The boy's father expressed his anger and hope for her suffering in prison on Facebook. The mother showed no emotion during her sentencing. The judge stated she suffers from a mental illness, but the crime was described as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors claimed the mother caused her son's illness for attention, while her lawyer argued she was a loving single mother and blamed the hospital for negligence. The mother plans to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains: Influenza A strain H3N2 and Influenza B strain B/Phuket. This new vaccine is a result of a spike in flu-related deaths in the Northern Hemisphere due to the vaccine's inability to effectively combat these strains. High-risk groups, such as the very young and very old, will receive free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. The vaccine also provides protection against Influenza A strain H1N1. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, urges everyone to get the vaccine, as it is worth waiting for and will help prevent more deaths per capita. The vaccine used in Australia this winter is a match for the global circulating strains and will be the same for the next Northern winter. Dr. Hampson recommends booking flu shots now due to the delayed stock arrival and emphasizes protecting high-risk groups and those around them.

The passage discusses the challenges facing the caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb, including an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could threaten the historic site's management. The passage highlights the financial crisis in Illinois, with Governor Bruce Rauner proposing to eliminate the state historic preservation agency managing sites like the tomb. The tomb has also been criticized for its historical character, with one historian describing it as 'a disappointment' and in 'incongruous art deco style'. The passage also mentions the tomb's recent repairs and renovations, which have cost over $2.5 million, and the ongoing efforts to waterproof the receiving vault and improve landscaping.

The passage discusses the revival of nineties and noughties fashion trends, highlighting several styles that have made a comeback, including JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, designer prints and double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The text also mentions celebrities who have embraced these trends, such as Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, Kylie Jenner, Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, Paris Hilton, and Selena Gomez.

A busy week featured four rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis. In China, hiring exotic dancers at wakes became illegal due to a vice crackdown. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life. The #KylieJennerChallenge trended, involving lip-plumping through sucking on a jar. Alice Barker, 102, went back in time with filmmakers. A school prom-posal referencing bombs led to accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp's appearance in 'Black Mass' trailer was unrecognizable. A pregnant woman announced her pregnancy with a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" reference. Lastly, a military dad photobombed his son's photo, earning kudos for originality.

The Miami Open is turning into National Cake Week as Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory with a giant cake. Following Andy Murray's 500th win, Serena reached the semi-finals with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 victory over Sabine Lisicki. Serena's hopes of facing her sister Venus were dashed after Venus's defeat to Carla Suarez Navarro. Serena, the World No. 1, aimed to stay alive in her closest tournament to a hometown event. Serena beat Sabine Lisicki in three sets to advance to the semi-finals, where she faced either Sloane Stephens or Simona Halep. In a battle of two big servers, Serena overcame the second set loss and avenged her Wimbledon 2013 shock defeat against Lisicki. Serena's opponent in the final will be Romania's Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5 to reach the Miami Open semi-finals.

The passage recounts the life and tragic death of Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist, entrepreneur, and advocate for free speech. Mahmud was known for her vibrant Second Floor Cafe in Karachi, which served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She was a passionate supporter of free speech in Pakistan, where it is often dangerous to express dissenting opinions. Sabeen Mahmud was assassinated by two gunmen who shot her dead at point-blank range after closing her cafe. She died from five bullet wounds, and her mother was also shot. Mahmud had recently organized a discussion group on a contentious topic, which led to her assassination. The discussion was on the topic of Baluchistan, a province in Pakistan where separatists have fought an insurgency for years, and where people have been disappearing regularly. The Lahore University of Management Sciences planned to host the discussion, but it was shut down by authorities. Mahmud insisted on holding the discussion at her cafe, despite previous death threats she had received for handling the topic. She was remembered as a Pakistani figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance, and her death sparked grief and

The passage discusses the plight of 82-year-old Mangu Ram, a Hindu traditional healer who has been living in Indian Kashmir as a refugee for the past 70 years since the partition of India. Despite being unable to own property or vote in state elections, Ram and thousands like him are hopeful that they may finally shed their refugee status after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party won a share of power in India's only Muslim-majority state. The refugees, known as West Pakistan refugees (WPRs), have been denied citizenship rights and live in poverty, with their situation worsened by the refusal of Indian Kashmir's rulers to grant them residential rights, including the right to buy land or work in the state government. The reluctance to grant them these rights stems from fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the state, which has special autonomy enshrined in the constitution. The passage also mentions ongoing conflict in Kashmir, with rebels fighting for independence or a merger with Pakistan.

Summary:

1. FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Chelsea this summer.
2. Chelsea has reportedly made an offer of around £4 million for Muto.
3. The offer includes a loan to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season.
4. Muto is looking for a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential.
5. FC Tokyo President Naoki Ogane confirmed the Chelsea offer.
6. Muto is pondering his future, seeking a team that suits him and allows for growth.
7. Real Zaragoza coach Ranko Popovic praised Muto's potential and intelligence.
8. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but prefers not to discuss the matter publicly.
9. Mourinho mentioned the importance of financial considerations and winning matches in the club's transfer policy.

The passage discusses the change in Australia's rugby policy, which allows them to select their best players regardless of where they play overseas, including in France. The author praises Australia for this decision, arguing that it is in line with the changing nature of the game and that it benefits the national team by allowing them to select the best players, regardless of their club affiliation. The author also criticizes England's policy of not selecting overseas players, pointing out that it is outdated and limits the selection of top-class performers like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage. The passage argues that England should follow Australia's example and select the best players for the national team, regardless of where they play, to ensure they have the best chance of winning the World Cup. The author also mentions Jonny Wilkinson and Nick Abendanon as examples of players who have improved their game by playing overseas.

The passage discusses the development of the Greenstone device by Open Garden, which acts as a beacon or booster to enhance off-the-grid wireless mesh networks, particularly for the Firechat app. Firechat, launched last year and downloaded over five million times, uses the Apple multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) to create a wireless mesh network that connects phones without a signal. Greenstone extends the range of these networks, addressing the 200 ft (61 meters) limit of direct communication. The device is egg-shaped, designed to work with Firechat, and can hold up to 1,000 recent messages. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with Firechat at a range of 20 ft (6 meters). Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell Greenstone, with the timeframe depending on these partnerships.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, aims to challenge the negative connotations surrounding the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive descriptor of her own physique. In a TED talk, she argues that words like'short', 'wife', and 'fat' are just honest descriptions of her identity, and should not be used as insults. Bustle discusses the societal programming that associates 'fat' with ugliness and highlights the issue of size discrimination in the workplace, which has risen by 66% in the past 30 years. She also notes that young girls often wish to be thinner, according to a study. Bustle performs burlesque, which exposes her audience to a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous way, hoping to change perceptions. She cites studies that show exposure to body diversity increases tolerance and acceptance of different body types. Bustle's TED talk, which has garnered nearly 38,000 views, has received mostly positive feedback, with some negative comments from trolls.

The passage discusses Theo Walcott and six of his Arsenal colleagues participating in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house, which the club has been associated with since 2013. Walcott has been overlooked for most of the season, appearing as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games. The team's first-team stars will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott hopes to make his first start for Arsenal since March 14 against Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, including items from Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, will be auctioned off at the end of May. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on PropStore.com on May 29. Some of the individual items are expected to fetch more than $40,000, with the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black valued at $40,000 and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas listed at $8,000. The auction features over 400 items from more than 50 productions, including films like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young. Items from Michael Jackson's 1988 Moonwalker film and 1983 Thriller music video will also be sold to the highest bidder. The auction is an exciting opportunity for collectors and fans of Rick Baker to own some of the

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, tragically died in the French Alps while on holiday with his family. He was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who loved skiing and modeled himself after TV adventurer Bear Grylls. Carwyn became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland where he fell over a 164 ft drop. Footprints in the snow led police to his body. The family described his death as leaving a vast void in their hearts and he will be greatly missed by his friends and classmates.

The passage recounts the story of 15-year-old Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay, who developed anorexia due to pressures put on teenagers to be a'size zero'. Laura became obsessed with her weight, hiding food and surviving on just one piece of fruit a day. Her dramatic weight loss led to a collapse and being put on a heart machine in intensive care. Laura has since spoken out about her two-year fight with anorexia and the pressures she felt to be thin. She has received support from eating disorder organizations and is now working with eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services for her recovery. Laura has also made it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to promote positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.

In the passage, Liverpool players, including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, unveil the club's new home kit designed by US sports brand New Balance. The kit features a gingham design and is the first from New Balance, who signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal to replace Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers. Fans express their support for Sterling to remain at the club, and the players discuss their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. The new kit includes a memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims and is designed by New Balance, who also created the home goalkeepers jersey.

The passage describes the creation of the largest high-definition map of dark matter, which is the first in a series of maps that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. The map, created by researchers at the University of Manchester, shows clumps of mysterious particles across 0.4 percent of the sky and is expected to allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe. The map was released at the American Physical Society's April meeting in Baltimore, Maryland, and was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device. The ultimate goal is to map 12.5 percent of the entire sky, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The project is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, which aims to test current cosmological theories by comparing the amounts of dark and visible matter.

Manchester United has officially made an approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who was named in van Gaal's 23-man World Cup squad last year, is enjoying a prolific season at PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. Despite Tottenham's £15 million offer being rebuffed last summer, Manchester United now appears to be in pole position to sign the youngster, with PSV technical director Marcel Brands stating that Depay is now worth more than that amount.

The passage describes a youth football match between Chelsea and Manchester City, where Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory. Tammy Abraham scored two goals, and Dominic Solanke scored the third goal. The match featured various players from both teams, with descriptions of their performances, strengths, and weaknesses. Chelsea's Tammy Abraham and Dominic Solanke were particularly noted for their contributions, while Manchester City's players were mentioned for their efforts and areas for improvement.

The passage discusses Republican presidential candidate Marco Rubio's views on same-sex marriage. He believes that people are born with a sexual preference and that the "definition of the institution of marriage should be between one man and one woman." Rubio is not against gay marriage but does not believe it should be a constitutional right. He argues that states should regulate marriage and that same-sex marriage should be decided through political debate rather than by courts. Despite his personal beliefs, Rubio stated that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, emphasizing his commitment to respecting personal choices and family relationships.

The passage is about Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple who embarked on a unique journey to discover different parts of the planet by cycling. They left their restaurant jobs in Manchester and have been traveling for almost a year, covering over 7,000 miles in 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation through websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and minimal expenses on food. Their only major expense is on food, which takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay. They have cycled through various countries, including France, Spain, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They plan to continue their journey into Asia, possibly crossing the Pacific and cycling the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, are suing the owner of a photo booth company, James Evans of Premier Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of their photo booth photos. The couple claims they were not informed of the photos until months after the wedding, and that Evans did not apologize for the incident. The couple is seeking an apology and compensation for negligence and breach of contract under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act. The case is set for trial in July, with mediation scheduled for the following day.

The passage discusses England full-back Mike Brown's cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback.
